question: Tell me about Yelan
answer: Yelan is a 5-star Hydro bow user in Genshin Impact who excels as a sub-DPS or off-field DPS, making her perfect for applying Hydro and triggering powerful elemental reactions like Vaporize, Electro-Charged, or Freeze while supporting your main damage dealer. Her playstyle revolves around dealing consistent Hydro damage while off-field, enabling other characters to shine as the main DPS. This makes her extremely flexible and valuable in a wide variety of team compositions. Her main source of damage comes from her Elemental Burst, Depth-Clarion Dice, which summons a Hydro-infused die that follows your active character and deals damage whenever they perform a Normal Attack. This effect continues even after you switch characters, which means Yelan can support your team even while she’s not on the field. Her Elemental Skill, Lingering Lifeline, lets her dash around, marking enemies in her path and dealing Hydro damage once the dash ends. This not only offers solid crowd control but also mobility to escape danger or quickly reposition. To build her effectively, your focus should be on Energy Recharge and HP-based stats to scale her Burst damage and ensure it’s always ready. The best artifact set for her is the 4-piece Emblem of Severed Fate, which boosts both Energy Recharge and Elemental Burst damage. For main stats, use Energy Recharge or HP% on the sands, Hydro DMG Bonus on the goblet, and Crit Rate or Crit DMG on the circlet, depending on your weapon and sub-stats. Sub-stats should prioritize Crit Rate, Crit DMG, Energy Recharge, and HP%. When it comes to weapons, her best-in-slot is the 5★ Aqua Simulacra, which gives Crit DMG and increases her HP and damage. For 4★ options, Favonius Warbow is great for generating energy and helping the whole team recharge their Bursts, while The Stringless boosts her Skill and Burst damage directly. Even 3★ bows like Slingshot can work well early on if you have good aim and are just starting out. Yelan’s passive talents further boost her effectiveness: one increases her damage based on her Max HP, another gradually increases your active character’s damage while her Burst is active, and her exploration passive reduces stamina consumption while sprinting—a small but helpful bonus when exploring Teyvat. She shines when teamed with characters who can take advantage of her Hydro application. Pyro characters like Hu Tao, Xiangling, and Yoimiya are great for Vaporize teams. Electro units like Raiden Shogun and Fischl enable Electro-Charged, and Cryo characters like Ganyu or Ayaka can trigger Freeze. Yelan pairs especially well with characters who use fast Normal Attacks to fully utilize her Burst’s effect. Even without any constellations, Yelan is already a top-tier support character. Her C1 adds a second charge to her Skill for extra Hydro application and mobility, while C2 and beyond boost her overall damage. C6 turns her into a main DPS by allowing her to fire special charged arrows rapidly during her Burst. In battle, a typical rotation involves using her Elemental Skill to dash and build energy, followed by her Elemental Burst, then switching to your main DPS to deal reaction-based damage while her Hydro die continues to strike. With this playstyle, Yelan provides consistent damage and support, making her easy to use and highly effective—even for new players. Overall, Yelan is a stylish, powerful, and versatile character who adds tremendous value to any team. Whether you're just starting out or a veteran player, investing in Yelan ensures you have a reliable Hydro support who keeps your enemies soaked and your team shining.

question: Tell me about Jean
answer: Jean is a 5-star Anemo character who wields a sword and serves as the Acting Grand Master of the Knights of Favonius in Mondstadt. She’s known for her sense of duty and hard work, and her character reflects the ideal balance between strength and care. In gameplay, Jean is a flexible unit who can serve as a healer, crowd controller, or even a physical damage dealer depending on how you build her. She’s especially useful in teams that need consistent healing or a bit of everything in one character. Jean’s talents are straightforward yet powerful. Her normal attack, Favonius Bladework, strikes up to five times in a combo. Holding down her charged attack unleashes a powerful slash at the cost of stamina. Her Elemental Skill, Gale Blade, summons a small storm that pulls enemies toward her and throws them when released. Holding the skill allows for better control of where enemies land, and throwing them into walls causes bonus damage. Her Elemental Burst, Dandelion Breeze, is a healing-and-damage combo that heals all party members based on her attack stat and deals Anemo damage to enemies around her. It also creates a healing field that persists and launches enemies inside it. Jean’s passive talents boost her utility further. Wind Companion gives her normal attacks a 50% chance to heal all party members based on her attack, providing steady healing during regular combat. Let the Wind Lead regenerates 20% of her energy when she uses her Elemental Burst, making her healing ability available more often. Guiding Breeze increases the chances of double output when crafting healing items, which is a nice bonus for resource management. There are two main ways to build Jean: as a healer/support or as a physical damage dealer. Her healing scales with her ATK stat, so in a support build, focusing on ATK% is key. Equip her with a 4-piece Viridescent Venerer artifact set for boosting Swirl reactions and reducing enemy resistances. Weapons like Freedom-Sworn, Favonius Sword, Sacrificial Sword, or the craftable Prototype Rancour work well, depending on whether you want more energy, cooldown resets, or attack stats. If you want to use Jean as a physical DPS, you can equip her with 2-piece Bloodstained Chivalry and 2-piece Pale Flame or 4-piece Gladiator’s Finale to increase her physical damage. Focus on CRIT Rate/DMG, ATK%, and Physical DMG Bonus for her main stats. While this playstyle is less common, it’s surprisingly viable with the right investment. Jean’s versatility makes her an easy fit into many teams. She synergizes well with Pyro characters like Xiangling or Diluc to trigger Anemo Swirl reactions and spread elemental effects. She also pairs well with Electro characters like Fischl or Raiden Shogun to benefit from more energy generation and extra reaction damage. Cryo characters can also be great allies, enhancing her crowd control capabilities and boosting reaction potential. Though Jean is great even at C0 (no constellations), unlocking constellations makes her even stronger. C1 boosts movement and attack speed after using her Burst, making her team more agile. C2 reduces damage taken and lowers enemy resistance. C4 helps with energy regeneration through her normal attacks, and C6 adds Anemo infusion to healed allies, boosting their elemental damage temporarily. In summary, Jean is one of the most dependable characters in Genshin Impact. Whether you’re just starting or already deep into the game, she offers healing, crowd control, and decent damage—all in one character. She fits into nearly any team and helps reduce downtime with her powerful healing and supportive abilities. If you’re lucky enough to have her, she’s absolutely worth investing in.

question: Tell me about Sucrose
answer: Sucrose is a 4-star Anemo Catalyst user who excels at supporting your team through crowd control and reaction amplification. As an alchemist from Mondstadt, she specializes in bio-alchemy and brings that expertise to the battlefield by increasing your team’s Elemental Mastery, making her an ideal support for reaction-heavy team compositions. If you're new to Genshin Impact and looking for a flexible, reaction-boosting support, Sucrose is a fantastic and budget-friendly choice. Her Elemental Skill, 'Astable Anemohypostasis Creation - 6308', summons a small Wind Spirit that pulls enemies together and deals Anemo damage. This ability is great for both grouping mobs and triggering Swirl reactions with other elements. Her Elemental Burst, 'Forbidden Creation - Isomer 75 / Type II', releases a larger spirit that continues to move and swirl around, dealing Anemo damage over time and absorbing one element (Pyro, Hydro, Cryo, or Electro) to deal additional elemental damage of that type. Both her Skill and Burst are powerful tools for spreading elemental effects and controlling the battlefield. What truly sets Sucrose apart is her Elemental Mastery scaling and her ability to share it with teammates. Her passive talent, 'Mollis Favonius', boosts the EM of characters who match the element she Swirls by 20% of her own EM. This makes her incredibly valuable in teams focused on reactions like Vaporize, Melt, Overloaded, or newer Dendro-related reactions such as Quicken and Hyperbloom. Another passive, 'Astable Invention', gives her a chance to double-craft character and weapon enhancement materials—bonus utility outside of battle. When it comes to weapons, Sucrose benefits most from Elemental Mastery or support-focused catalysts. The 3-star Thrilling Tales of Dragon Slayers is surprisingly powerful, offering a huge ATK boost to the next character after she swaps out. Sacrificial Fragments is another excellent choice, providing EM and a chance to reset her Skill cooldown for more Swirls. For more advanced or niche setups, Mappa Mare or Hakushin Ring can also work depending on your team. For artifacts, your best bet is a 4-piece Viridescent Venerer set. This not only enhances her Anemo damage and Swirl power, but it also reduces the elemental resistance of enemies to the element Swirled—boosting your main DPS’s output even further. For main stats, go full Elemental Mastery on Sands, Goblet, and Circlet to maximize Swirl and her EM-sharing potential. Until you can get a full Viridescent set, mixing 2-piece sets with EM or Instructor can be a good placeholder. Her Constellations aren’t necessary for her to function, but they do add value. C1 gives her an additional Skill charge, C2 increases her Burst duration and improves crowd control, and C6 gives a significant Elemental Mastery bonus to the whole team after she uses her Burst. If you plan to use her often in reaction teams, these constellations can be very impactful. Sucrose fits beautifully into teams focused on Elemental Reactions. She pairs especially well with Pyro, Hydro, and Electro characters. Popular teams include Hu Tao + Xingqiu + Sucrose for Vaporize, or Raiden + Fischl + Sucrose + Dendro unit for Aggravate or Hyperbloom. She can even serve as a driver in Electro-Charged teams, triggering reactions while supporting from the field. In summary, Sucrose is a top-tier 4-star support that new players should absolutely consider building. Her ability to group enemies, trigger powerful Swirl reactions, and buff your team’s Elemental Mastery makes her a valuable addition to many team comps. She's flexible, easy to build with 3-star weapons, and incredibly impactful when used correctly. With just a bit of investment in Elemental Mastery, Sucrose can become the backbone of your reaction-based team.

question: Tell me about Kazuha
answer: Kazuha is a 5-star Anemo (wind) sword user from Inazuma, known for his graceful playstyle and powerful team buffs. As one of the most versatile and effective support characters in the game, Kazuha brings immense value to almost any team. Whether you're new to Genshin Impact or just pulled him from a rerun banner, this guide will walk you through how to build and play him efficiently. Kazuha’s role is primarily that of an Anemo support or sub-DPS. His job is to boost your team's elemental damage, group enemies together, and trigger Swirl reactions that deal AoE damage. His Elemental Skill, Chihayaburu, can either be tapped for a quick lift or held for a stronger suction effect that pulls enemies in and launches Kazuha into the air. From there, you can perform a Plunge Attack, which deals AoE Anemo damage. If your skill absorbs an element like Pyro, Hydro, Electro, or Cryo, the plunge attack will deal additional elemental damage based on that element. His Elemental Burst, 'Kazuha Slash', is one of the best team utility abilities in the game. It creates a swirling Anemo field that absorbs an element it comes into contact with and continues to deal AoE elemental damage over time. This skill has an 8-second duration and a 15-second cooldown, giving it good uptime. More importantly, it triggers Swirl constantly, which is key to Kazuha’s strength. One of Kazuha’s most important features is his Ascension 4 passive, which grants your team a bonus to elemental damage based on his Elemental Mastery (EM). Every time he triggers a Swirl, your team gains a damage bonus to the element Swirled, scaling at 0.04% per point of EM. This might sound small, but it adds up quickly—especially since Kazuha can Swirl multiple elements and has high EM. For example, at 800 EM, he grants 32% elemental damage bonus, which is massive for any elemental DPS. Because of this, the most effective way to build Kazuha is by focusing on Elemental Mastery. Although his abilities scale with ATK and Crit too, stacking EM not only improves his personal Swirl damage but also enhances your whole team’s output. Swirl is a transformative reaction, which means it scales with Kazuha’s level and EM—not his ATK or Crit—so it's highly recommended to prioritize EM unless you're building him for niche DPS roles (which is uncommon and less efficient). To get the most out of Kazuha, you should level him to 90, since Swirl damage is based on character level. For talent priority, max his Elemental Burst first, followed by Normal Attack (for plunge scaling) and Elemental Skill. Even though Kazuha is a support, leveling his talents improves his grouping and damage efficiency. When it comes to artifacts, there’s really only one top-tier option: the 4-piece Viridescent Venerer set. It increases Anemo damage, boosts Swirl damage, and more importantly, reduces enemy resistance to the Swirled element by 40%. This makes it an incredibly strong support set for any Anemo character, and especially for Kazuha, who can Swirl multiple elements in one rotation. For main stats, aim for: Sands: Elemental Mastery or Energy Recharge (if needed) Goblet: Elemental Mastery Circlet: Elemental Mastery For substats, prioritize Energy Recharge (until you can consistently use your Burst), Crit Rate (if using Favonius Sword), and any extra EM or offensive stats. Speaking of weapons, Kazuha’s best-in-slot is the Freedom-Sworn sword, which boosts EM and increases team damage when you trigger a reaction. However, it's a 5-star limited weapon and not necessary. A fantastic 4-star option is the Favonius Sword, which generates energy particles for your team and helps reduce Kazuha’s energy needs. Just remember—you’ll need a bit of Crit Rate to trigger its passive. If you don’t have that, Sacrificial Sword is another strong pick, letting you reset his Skill and Swirl more often. Finally, Iron Sting is a great free-to-play option, offering decent EM and reaction-based damage. Kazuha fits into almost every elemental team, especially those that rely on reactions. He's amazing with Pyro, Hydro, Cryo, or Electro DPS characters. Teams like Xiangling + Xingqiu, Raiden Hypercarry, Hu Tao Vaporize, Ganyu Melt, and even Freeze teams with Cryo carries like Ayaka or Rosaria all benefit from Kazuha’s Swirls and buffs. He’s also useful in teams that don’t rely heavily on reactions, such as Mono-element setups, where he buffs a single element with massive impact. When playing Kazuha, always aim to Swirl the right element to buff your main DPS. For example, if you're playing Hu Tao, Swirl Pyro. In a Freeze team, Swirl Cryo. Kazuha can even double Swirl in some teams—swirling Hydro and Pyro at the same time, or Electro and Hydro in Taser comps—buffing both elements. This makes him extremely valuable in multi-element reaction teams. In terms of constellations, Kazuha is already incredibly strong at C0. You don’t need any constellations to make him shine. However, C2 is particularly powerful—it grants 200 Elemental Mastery to both Kazuha and your team when you use his Burst. This turns him into a pseudo-Sucrose and significantly boosts team damage. C1 gives a small quality-of-life cooldown reset, while C6 allows him to become a main DPS with Anemo-infused attacks, though it changes how you build and play him. To sum it all up, Kazuha is one of the most powerful, flexible, and fun support characters in Genshin Impact. He makes any elemental team better with his Swirl damage, team buffs, and crowd control. He’s incredibly easy to build around Elemental Mastery and works well with both budget and high-end setups. Whether you're running him in Freeze, Vaporize, Taser, or Mono-element teams, he’s always going to be an asset—and once you start playing him, you'll see why he's considered one of the best 5-stars in the game.

question: Tell me about Sayu
answer: Sayu is a unique and fun support character in Genshin Impact who excels at healing, swirling elements, and rolling around the battlefield. For a new player, understanding how to build her might seem complicated at first, but once you get a grip on her mechanics, she becomes one of the most versatile and enjoyable units to use. Her healing is the most important part of her kit and comes primarily from her Elemental Burst, which summons a Daruma that heals allies and damages enemies based on her attack stat. However, Sayu also heals when she triggers Swirl reactions thanks to one of her passive talents, which scales with Elemental Mastery. That’s why building her with Elemental Mastery not only improves her Swirl damage but also boosts the healing from those reactions. Her Elemental Skill, which lets her roll around and deal Anemo damage, can be held or tapped. Holding it deals more damage and generates more energy particles, making it very useful when used correctly. Ideally, you should briefly hold and then release to get the most out of it without waiting for the full cooldown. For artifacts, the best set for Sayu is the 4-piece Viridescent Venerer, which increases Anemo and Swirl damage and reduces enemy resistances to the element you swirl. This makes her especially powerful in teams that rely on elemental reactions. Stat-wise, focusing on Elemental Mastery for all three main artifact pieces—Sands, Goblet, and Circlet—is generally optimal for both damage and healing. However, if you find her healing lacking, you can replace the Circlet with a Healing Bonus one. Energy Recharge is also very important for her to use her Burst consistently, so try to find it in sub-stats or use an Energy Recharge weapon to make up for it. Weapon-wise, Sayu benefits most from Energy Recharge claymores like the Favonius Greatsword or Sacrificial Greatsword. These help her regain energy more efficiently so she can keep healing. If you already have enough Energy Recharge from artifacts, you can opt for an Elemental Mastery weapon like Rain Slasher or even a simple three-star Bloodtainted Greatsword. High-end options like Wolf’s Gravestone or Skyward Pride also work great if you have them, but they’re not necessary for her to function well. In terms of team compositions, Sayu can either be the centerpiece in a team that revolves around her rolling skill—especially effective when combined with Xiangling’s Pyronado—or act as a general Anemo support like Jean. She’s very flexible and can fit into many reaction-based teams, particularly those that benefit from Swirl and need a reliable healer. She works well with characters like Fischl, Xiangling, or Xingqiu, who can provide continuous elemental application for her to swirl. Even in teams where the main carry isn’t Anemo, she can help boost their damage by reducing resistances and keeping the team healthy. Sayu is great at what she does even at Constellation 0, though her Constellation 1 gives a big quality-of-life boost by letting her Daruma heal and attack at the same time. Her Constellation 6 is also fantastic, turning Elemental Mastery into a stronger stat for both healing and damage. But even without any constellations, she’s perfectly functional and enjoyable. Overall, Sayu is a fantastic support character with a playful kit, making her a great pick for both new and veteran players. She adds a lot of utility, mobility, and fun to any team she’s in, and with the right build, she can become an invaluable part of your lineup.

question: Tell me about Wanderer
answer: Wanderer, also known as Scaramouche, is a powerful and stylish Anemo DPS character who thrives on being the center of attention in a team. As a new player, understanding how to use him can be a bit overwhelming at first, but once you grasp the mechanics of his unique kit, he becomes one of the most fun and flashy characters in Genshin Impact. The core of Wanderer’s kit revolves around his Elemental Skill, which lifts him into the air and allows him to hover while performing enhanced Normal and Charged Attacks. During this mode, he gains a special stamina-like bar that depletes with actions like attacking or dashing. His attacks in this state are significantly buffed, and this is where the bulk of his damage comes from. He also has passives that add to this kit—when he swirls certain elements like Pyro, Hydro, Electro, or Cryo during this mode, he gains buffs such as bonus ATK, Crit Rate, Energy generation, or more hover time. This allows for interesting synergies with elemental support characters that can pre-apply these elements before he enters his skill. His Elemental Burst, while flashy and satisfying, is more of a bonus than a core part of his rotation. It costs 60 energy and deals a burst of AoE Anemo damage, but you don’t need to use it every rotation. Instead, you can focus on keeping his skill up and weaving in the burst every other rotation when energy allows. Talent-wise, leveling his Normal Attack first is crucial, followed by his Skill. His Burst should be your last priority unless you have Constellation 2, which directly buffs it. Artifact-wise, Wanderer's best set is the Desert Pavilion Chronicle. This 4-piece set buffs Anemo damage, increases attack speed, and gives a massive boost to Normal, Charged, and Plunging Attack damage after a Charged Attack hits—perfect for his playstyle. If you don’t have access to that, a good alternative is the Shimenawa’s Reminiscence set, which also buffs attacks significantly but drains energy, making it harder to use his Burst frequently. Two-piece mixes of Anemo Damage Bonus and ATK% sets also work well if you’re starting out or don’t want to farm a specific domain. Stat-wise, prioritize ATK% on the Sands, Anemo DMG Bonus on the Goblet, and Crit Rate or Crit DMG on the Circlet, balancing based on your weapon. Energy Recharge is not a major focus since his Burst isn’t core to his rotation, but a little can help if you want to use it more often. When it comes to weapons, his signature 5-star catalyst is naturally the best, giving him Crit stats and damage boosts tailored to his kit. However, he has many viable alternatives. Crit-based weapons like Lost Prayer or Kagura’s Verity work well, while 4-star options like The Widsith, Solar Pearl, and Dodoco Tales (if you have it) are excellent budget picks. These all offer good offensive stats and effects that mesh well with his damage output. Even if you missed event weapons, Blackcliff Agate or the Map of Mare can be used in a pinch, though they are slightly weaker. In terms of team comps, Wanderer can function in a few distinct roles. Most commonly, he’s played as a hypercarry surrounded by buffers like Faruzan (who boosts Anemo damage and shreds resistance), Bennett (for his massive ATK boost), and someone like Layla or Zhongli for shielding. Faruzan is a very important unit for maximizing Wanderer’s damage, although she can be difficult to build at low constellations due to her high Energy Recharge needs. Alternatively, you can use Wanderer as a “driver” in taser-style teams with supports like Fischl, Xingqiu, Yelan, or Beidou, where he swirls and triggers reactions while dealing damage through Normal or Charged Attacks. Ultimately, Wanderer is incredibly versatile and very enjoyable to play. His fast-paced, aerial combat feels unique, and while he lacks interruption resistance, pairing him with a shielder can solve that issue. Whether you want to build a team around his swirling style or run him as a reaction enabler, he can shine in many compositions. He’s viable at C0 and scales well with constellations, especially C2 and C6, but doesn’t require them to be effective. For a new player looking for a flashy and satisfying on-field DPS, Wanderer is a fantastic and rewarding choice.

question: Tell me about Lynette
answer: Lynette is a four-star Anemo support character who offers a mix of utility, swirl support, and a special mechanic called *Usia-aligned damage*, making her especially useful in Fontaine content. As a new player, she’s an excellent free character to help you learn about reaction-based teams and Anemo utility, all while fitting into a wide variety of team compositions. Her Elemental Skill can be pressed or held. A tap performs a quick hit of Anemo damage with surprisingly good scaling, while holding lets her dash around before striking a marked enemy. When her thrust lands, she heals a portion of her HP instantly, then drains some current HP over time, which usually results in a net HP gain. This HP-drain mechanic also synergizes with Fontaine-specific artifact sets and weapons. The skill also generates energy particles and, importantly, applies Usia-aligned damage. This is useful against certain Fontaine enemies and bosses, especially those that have mechanics or shields tied to Usia or Pneuma alignment. Her Elemental Burst is a summoned cat-shaped box that deals AoE Anemo damage and continuously applies swirl to enemies nearby. It can infuse with Pyro, Hydro, Cryo, or Electro based on what it touches first, and it also taunts enemies. The taunt isn’t perfect but is more reliable than most due to the burst’s durability and 12-second duration. It costs 70 energy, so building Lynette with enough Energy Recharge is important to use it consistently. Additionally, she has passive talents that give your whole team bonus ATK (based on how many different elements are in your team) and boost her Burst’s damage when it’s infused with an element. When building Lynette, the 4-piece Viridescent Venerer set is almost always the go-to choice. It’s perfect for any Anemo support, increasing Anemo damage and boosting your team’s elemental damage by shredding enemy resistance to swirled elements. If another Anemo support on your team is already using that set, or if you want to focus on Lynette’s own damage, you can use other sets like Noblesse Oblige for burst support or Emblem of Severed Fate for energy-heavy builds. As for stats, aim for Energy Recharge on the Sands (if you need it), Anemo DMG Bonus on the Goblet, and Crit Rate or Crit DMG on the Circlet. Substats should focus on ER (until you can burst comfortably), Crit, and ATK%. Elemental Mastery is also viable if you want to boost her swirl damage, especially in reaction-heavy teams. For weapons, Lynette has two main paths: support-oriented swords that help with energy, and offensive swords that boost her personal damage. Sacrificial Sword and Favonius Sword are her top-tier four-star options. Sacrificial can give her a second Skill use, which means more particles and damage, especially at higher refinements. Favonius Sword generates team-wide energy particles when Lynette crits, helping both her and her teammates recharge faster. If you’re looking for damage, weapons like Festering Desire, Finale of the Deep, or the new Battle Pass sword Wolf-Fang are solid picks. Five-star options like Freedom-Sworn or Mistsplitter Reforged work too, but aren’t necessary—her four-star options are already great. Team-wise, Lynette is extremely flexible. She fits well into any team that benefits from swirl reactions. This includes Vaporize, Overload, Freeze, Electro-Charged, and Hyperbloom comps. She supports characters like Hu Tao, Xiangling, Ayaka, Yelan, Xingqiu, Fischl, and Beidou by swirling their elements and reducing enemy resistances. She’s especially valuable in teams that lack a top-tier Anemo support like Kazuha or Sucrose, giving newer or free-to-play players access to swirl utility without needing to pull for rarer characters. In Fontaine, her Usia-aligned damage gives her an edge in certain domains and against special bosses. If you have her sixth constellation, she can even serve as a main on-field driver in taser-style teams, swirling Hydro and Electro while dishing out respectable damage herself. Overall, Lynette is a well-rounded, free Anemo unit who brings a lot to the table. She’s not as powerful as five-star Anemo supports like Kazuha or Venti, but she has a unique niche with her Usia-aligned mechanic, solid personal damage, good energy generation, and flexible team compatibility. Whether you’re building her as a pure support, a hybrid sub-DPS, or even a driver at C6, she’s a very worthwhile investment—especially for newer players building their first reaction-focused teams.

question: Tell me about Lyney
answer: Lyney is a five-star Pyro bow user with a unique and stylish playstyle centered around charged shots. Unlike many bow characters who are reaction-based or focused on elemental skills, Lyney is all about spamming Level 2 charged attacks for strong single-target Pyro damage. His gameplay feels a bit like Ganyu’s in terms of mechanics, but instead of ice blooms, Lyney fires powerful “Prop Arrows” that can spawn pyro-hatted companions, deal extra damage, and create AoE when detonated. His kit is elegant but has specific team and stat needs, so building him right is key to unlocking his full potential. The core of Lyney’s playstyle is his Level 2 charged shot. Firing this not only deals high damage but also consumes a portion of his HP if he’s above 60%, creating a “Prop Surplus Stack” and summoning a Grin-Malkin Hat. These hats taunt enemies and eventually explode to deal bonus Pyro damage—this damage scales with his charged attack stat, meaning it benefits directly from the same buffs. Lyney’s Elemental Skill consumes all stacks to do AoE Pyro damage and heals him based on HP lost, making it a clean way to reset his HP while also contributing to damage. His Elemental Burst turns him into a cat-like performer that dashes around dealing Pyro damage and ends with a large AoE blast. You can cancel it early to get the final hit faster, which is useful for optimizing rotations. One of Lyney’s most important passives gives him up to 100% bonus damage against enemies affected by Pyro, scaling higher the more Pyro teammates are in the party. Because of this, he thrives in mono Pyro teams, where his bonus can shine. Adding non-Pyro characters who overwrite Pyro reactions—like Hydro or Cryo—diminishes his potential, so his teams are built more around maintaining constant Pyro aura than chasing vaporize or melt reactions. For artifacts, Lyney’s best-in-slot is the 4-piece *Marechaussee Hunter* set. The 2-piece bonus boosts his Normal and Charged Attack damage, and the 4-piece gives him up to 36% Crit Rate whenever his HP changes, which it does constantly through his own mechanics and healing. This set is basically tailor-made for him and works incredibly well, as long as you’re rotating properly and keeping HP fluctuations going. If you don’t have this set yet, viable substitutes include Lavawalker for Pyro-specific damage, Wanderer’s Troupe for charged shot power, or even Vermillion Hereafter if you’re willing to manage its burst-related bonuses. Main stats should be ATK% Sands, Pyro DMG Bonus Goblet, and Crit DMG or Crit Rate Circlet, depending on your weapon and overall Crit ratio. Aim for around 120–140% Energy Recharge if you plan to use his Burst every rotation. Weapon-wise, Lyney has great flexibility. His signature 5-star weapon, The First Great Magic, is his best option, boosting charge shot damage and scaling attack with more Pyro teammates. Aqua Simulacra is close behind with massive Crit DMG. Other 5-star bows like Thundering Pulse or Polar Star also work well, though the latter can overcap Crit Rate. On the 4-star side, his best free-to-play weapon is *Prototype Crescent*, which gives huge ATK boosts on weak point hits—great if you can aim reliably. Battle Pass bows like The Viridescent Hunt or the new Scion of the Blazing Sun also perform well, particularly in single-target fights. Even options like Blackcliff Warbow or Song of Stillness are serviceable if you’re building around their strengths. Team-wise, Lyney shines in mono Pyro comps. His best support is Bennett, who provides ATK buffs, healing, Pyro resonance, and enables frequent HP fluctuations to trigger artifact effects. For defensive utility, Zhongli is ideal thanks to his shield and resistance shred. You can also run other Pyro defensive units like Dehya (with her resistance to interruption), or even Xinyan if you’ve built her. As a flex support or buffer, Anemo units like Kazuha or Sucrose can swirl Pyro and boost his damage. Kazuha in particular is excellent due to his elemental damage boost. Shangling is another strong choice, offering tons of off-field Pyro damage and synergy with mono Pyro setups. Some niche choices include Lynette for swirl and taunt synergy or Layla/Kirara for off-element shielders who don’t interfere with Pyro uptime. Overall, Lyney is a high-damage main DPS who scales incredibly well with the right team and setup. He’s not the easiest character to play due to his reliance on aimed charged shots and his need for a stable team environment to maintain uptime on Pyro aura and buffs. But if you enjoy a more technical, sharpshooting style and can build around him with strong Pyro supports, he can be a very rewarding and powerful option—especially when his best set and signature weapon come into play.

question: Tell me about Freminet
answer: Freminet is a 4-star Cryo claymore user who offers a refreshing twist on Genshin Impact’s combat system through a pressure-based combo mechanic. Instead of relying on elemental reactions like Melt or Freeze, Freminet is built around dealing strong physical damage, complemented by periodic Cryo application. His Elemental Skill is the heart of his kit—it activates a state called *Pers Timer*, during which his normal attacks generate pressure. When that pressure reaches Level 4, his Skill deals bonus Cryo and heavy physical damage, making for a satisfying burst of power at the end of his combo loop. This system encourages rhythmic play and gives Freminet a unique flow, rewarding players who like precise timing and consistency over quick swapping or reaction-heavy bursts. His Elemental Burst is more of a supportive tool—it deals AoE Cryo damage and resets the cooldown of his Skill, letting you quickly jump back into the combo loop. Though it’s not his primary damage source, it’s still useful for keeping up Cryo application and helps maintain rotation flow. His passive talents also tie into his kit neatly, increasing his ATK after hitting opponents with his Skill, and enhancing damage when triggering Shatter. While Shatter isn't the focus of his kit, it adds a bit of bonus damage if you have Hydro or Geo teammates that can freeze enemies. Freminet’s constellations enhance his gameplay without fundamentally changing it, offering a balance of quality-of-life improvements and raw power boosts. His **C1**, *Dreams of the Seething Deep*, gives him a 15% Crit Rate buff for 5 seconds after using his Skill—an easy-to-trigger bonus that makes building Crit stats easier and improves his consistency early in rotations. **C2**, *Penguins and the Land of Plenty*, raises his Skill level by 3, directly buffing the damage of his core combo, especially the powerful explosion at Pressure Level 4. **C3**, *Song of the Eddies and Bleached Sands*, increases the Burst level by 3, which helps but isn’t as impactful since the Burst isn’t his main damage source. **C4**, *Dance of the Snowy Moon and Flute*, is a big gameplay improvement—it extends his *Pers Timer* state and allows an additional pressure stack, making it easier to hit Level 4 and keeping him in his high-damage state longer. **C5**, *Nights of Hearth and Happiness*, adds 3 levels to his Normal Attack talent, further enhancing his pressure-generating swings. Finally, **C6**, *Moment of Waking and Resolve*, is his strongest power spike, massively increasing the explosion damage of his Level 4 pressure release by adding 80% of his ATK and 200% of his Physical DMG Bonus. This turns his final hit into a devastating strike that feels truly rewarding to land. When building Freminet, the best artifact set is the 4-piece *Pale Flame*, which increases physical damage and boosts ATK when his Skill hits enemies. This synergizes perfectly with his pressure-loop playstyle. If you’re missing good Pale Flame pieces, a 2-piece combo with *Bloodstained Chivalry* is a solid fallback. For stats, aim for ATK% on the Sands, Physical DMG Bonus on the Goblet, and Crit Rate or Crit DMG on the Circlet, depending on your overall ratio. You can run some Energy Recharge in substats to help with Burst uptime, but it’s not a priority. He doesn’t scale with Elemental Mastery, so focus purely on offensive stats. Freminet’s best weapon for F2P players is the craftable *Snow-Tombed Starsilver*, which fits both thematically and mechanically. It boosts physical damage and has a decent ATK stat. *Serpent Spine* is also a top-tier 4-star option if you manage its passive with shields. Among 5-stars, *Song of Broken Pines* is his best choice, offering a Physical DMG bonus and team ATK buff. *The Unforged* or *Redhorn Stonethresher* are also viable, though Redhorn's DEF scaling isn’t ideal. *Prototype Archaic* is a good early-game alternative if you don’t have access to better options. Team-wise, Freminet shines as an on-field physical DPS in superconduct-focused teams. Pairing him with Electro characters like Fischl or Raiden Shogun allows you to reduce enemy physical resistance, boosting his damage. Diona is a strong Cryo support option, offering shielding, healing, and Cryo resonance. Zhongli is arguably the best defensive pick, giving you strong shields and reducing enemy resistance. You can also consider characters like Mika, who directly buffs physical damage, or Rosaria, who helps with Crit Rate and resonance. Freminet stands out from other 4-stars by delivering a focused, timing-based playstyle with strong physical DPS potential. He’s not the most flashy or flexible unit, but for players who enjoy controlling a main carry with consistent, rhythmic output and a satisfying combo payoff, Freminet offers something genuinely fresh. While his full potential shines most with some constellations—especially C1 for Crit, C4 for better uptime, and C6 for huge finishers—he’s more than capable of handling his role at C0 with the right build and team.

question: Tell me about Albedo
answer: Albedo is a 5-star Geo sword user who excels as an off-field sub-DPS, delivering consistent and reliable damage through his Elemental Skill while requiring very little field time or energy. He’s incredibly low-maintenance and efficient, making him a valuable asset in a variety of team comps—especially those that benefit from off-field Geo application or need a solid second DPS for split teams. His playstyle is simple but effective, and he's especially appealing to players who want to set-and-forget a source of damage while focusing on their main DPS. Albedo’s Elemental Skill, *Abiogenesis: Solar Isotoma*, creates a Geo construct that deals AoE Geo damage every 2 seconds when enemies inside its field are hit. These damage instances, called *transient blossoms*, scale entirely with Albedo’s DEF, which makes building him straightforward and efficient. The construct also generates energy and acts as a small platform, which can be used for vertical mobility. It’s worth noting that this skill persists even if you swap characters, allowing Albedo to deal consistent damage from off-field. His Elemental Burst, *Rite of Progeniture: Tectonic Tide*, is a quick Geo slash that deals AoE Geo damage and spawns several small Geo blooms (Fatal Blossoms) if Solar Isotoma is active. It scales with ATK, unlike his Skill, but it's still useful for a bit of burst damage and crystalize reactions. Albedo's constellations improve his overall consistency and damage output. **C1**, *Flower of Eden*, gives energy when blossoms trigger, making his Burst much easier to use regularly. **C2**, *Opening of Phanerozoic*, adds a stacking 15% DEF bonus when your characters gain crystals from the Crystallize reaction, directly boosting his Skill damage. **C3** increases his Skill level, and **C4** buffs your active character’s plunge attack damage, which is niche but fun in Xiao teams. **C5** boosts his Burst level, and **C6** adds a powerful mechanic: when Albedo triggers a Transient Blossom, his Elemental Mastery increases by 125 for 10 seconds—great in reaction-based teams like Sunfire or Geo-overload variants. While he’s excellent at C0, his constellations—especially C1 and C2—add nice quality-of-life and damage improvements without drastically changing how he’s played. For artifacts, Albedo’s best set is the **4-piece Husk of Opulent Dreams**, which provides DEF and Geo DMG Bonus. It synergizes perfectly with his Skill scaling and is ideal for maximizing his off-field damage. If you haven’t farmed Husk yet, you can also use a **2-piece Archaic Petra + 2-piece Husk** combo or **2-piece DEF% sets** until you get better pieces. For stats, prioritize **DEF% on Sands**, **Geo DMG Bonus on the Goblet**, and **Crit Rate or Crit DMG on the Circlet**, depending on your weapon. Substats should focus on Crit Rate, Crit DMG, and DEF%. You don't need Elemental Mastery or ATK%, since his Skill doesn't benefit from those. In terms of weapons, Albedo’s **best-in-slot 4-star weapon** is the **Cinnabar Spindle**, which was a free event sword tailored for him. It boosts his Skill DMG based on DEF, making it perfect if you got it during the event. If not, **Harbinger of Dawn** is a strong 3-star option with high Crit DMG and Crit Rate at full HP. It’s extremely efficient and often outperforms even some 5-star options for Albedo. Other decent picks include **Festering Desire** or **Freedom-Sworn** if you're running him in reaction-based comps, though they aren’t optimal for his usual DEF-scaling build. Team-wise, Albedo fits seamlessly into many lineups. He’s a staple in **double Geo teams**, often paired with **Zhongli** for resonance and shields. He also works beautifully with **Xiao**, whose plunge attacks benefit from Albedo’s off-field damage and occasional Burst buffs. Albedo fits into **mono Geo teams** with characters like **Itto**, **Gorou**, and **Ningguang**, providing consistent background DPS and energy. You can also slot him into **reaction teams** like **Sunfire (Jean + Bennett)** or **overload comps**, especially if you run him at C6 for the bonus Elemental Mastery. Because he generates energy, requires minimal field time, and can be built with cost-effective weapons and artifacts, Albedo is one of the most plug-and-play sub-DPS characters in the game. Overall, Albedo is a prime example of a sub-DPS who brings reliable value to nearly any team. He doesn’t need a fancy rotation, rare gear, or high investment to perform well. His constellations improve his role further but aren’t necessary. For players looking to boost team damage without micromanaging another active unit, or for those who need a solid off-field contributor in Abyss split teams, Albedo is a smart and satisfying choice.

question: Tell me about Ninghuang
answer: Ningguang is a 4-star Geo catalyst user who functions best as a burst-focused main or sub-DPS. She’s known for her ability to deal high Geo damage, scale well with investment, and even serve as a carry in both early and late-game content. Ningguang’s unique mechanic revolves around her Jade Screen and her charged attacks, allowing her to output strong single-target damage while remaining one of the more stylish and satisfying characters to play. Her playstyle is clean, straightforward, and rewarding for players who enjoy positioning and quick bursts of damage. Her Elemental Skill, **Jade Screen**, creates a wall of Geo energy that blocks projectiles and scales with her Max HP, but most importantly, it serves as a buffing tool. When Ningguang fires a charged attack through the screen, the damage is amplified. This is key to optimizing her damage output. Jade Screen also applies Geo and can be used strategically to create shields when crystallizing with other elements. Her **Elemental Burst**, **Starshatter**, unleashes a flurry of homing gems that deal high Geo damage to enemies. If her Jade Screen is present when she casts her Burst, it will fire additional gems, massively increasing damage. This synergy makes her burst combos particularly potent when set up correctly. Ningguang’s **constellations** enhance her kit in meaningful ways, especially if you plan to use her as your primary or secondary DPS. **C1**, *Piercing Fragments*, allows her Normal Attacks to deal AoE damage—nice for group fights. **C2**, *Shock Effect*, reduces the Elemental Skill cooldown when the screen is shattered, giving you more frequent access to her screen buff and energy generation. **C3** increases her Burst level by 3, directly improving her most important source of damage. **C4**, *Exquisite be the Jade, Outshining All Beneath*, grants all party members a 10% Geo DMG bonus when they pass through the screen—very useful in mono Geo teams or with other Geo supports. **C5** boosts her Normal Attack talent, and **C6**, *Grandeur Be the Seven Stars*, causes Ningguang to spawn 7 Star Jades after using her Burst, which can be unleashed instantly with a Normal Attack for big follow-up damage. This constellation significantly increases her burst combo and flow, making her feel smoother and much more powerful as a main DPS. For artifacts, Ningguang’s best set is **2-piece Archaic Petra + 2-piece ATK% (like Gladiator’s or Shimenawa’s)**. This combination gives her Geo DMG and flat ATK%, both of which are crucial since her damage scales off ATK and Geo Bonus. For more personal damage at higher investment, you can also run **4-piece Archaic Petra**, especially if you’re supporting with elemental pickups for team buffs, or **4-piece Retracing Bolide** if you're consistently shielded (e.g., with Zhongli). As for main stats: use **ATK% Sands**, **Geo DMG Bonus Goblet**, and **Crit Rate or Crit DMG Circlet**, depending on your weapon and ratio. Substats should focus on Crit, ATK%, and some Energy Recharge. Weapon-wise, Ningguang benefits a lot from weapons that offer Crit stats and ATK bonuses. Her **best-in-slot 5-star weapon** is **Lost Prayer to the Sacred Winds**, which boosts Crit Rate and increases Elemental DMG over time, suiting her on-field DPS role. **Memory of Dust** is also strong, especially with shields, offering ATK stacking. **Solar Pearl**, a Battle Pass catalyst, is one of her best 4-star options, providing both Crit Rate and Normal/Burst DMG increases. **The Widsith** is another excellent choice—it’s a stat stick that grants rotating buffs, and Ningguang can capitalize on whichever she gets thanks to her short rotations. For F2P players, **Thrilling Tales of Dragon Slayers** isn’t ideal unless she’s built purely as a support, so something like **Twin Nephrite** or **Mappa Mare** can be temporary options. Team-wise, Ningguang is very flexible. She performs well in **mono Geo teams**, often paired with **Zhongli**, **Albedo**, or **Gorou** if you’re using multiple Geo units. Zhongli is especially valuable for his shield and resistance shred, which lets Ningguang focus entirely on damage. Ningguang also fits into **Geo-Charged teams** with Fischl, Beidou, or Xingqiu, who can provide off-field damage while she executes her burst combos. You can even build a dual carry comp with Ningguang and a character like Noelle or Yanfei, swapping in and out for big bursts. In short, Ningguang is a stylish and effective Geo DPS who can shine with relatively low investment and scale beautifully with constellations. She has a straightforward kit that’s easy to learn and rewarding to master, offering a clean, bursty playstyle and fantastic synergy in Geo-heavy comps. Whether you’re looking for a dependable sub-DPS or a full-fledged main DPS, Ningguang delivers with elegance and power.

question: Tell me about Zhongli
answer: Zhongli is a 5-star Geo polearm user who excels as the strongest defensive support in Genshin Impact while also offering solid burst and sub-DPS utility. His most defining feature is his **unmatched shield strength**, which not only protects your team but also shreds enemy resistances, making him a universal fit in nearly any team composition. Whether you’re a new player looking for safety or a veteran building high-end Abyss comps, Zhongli provides immense value with minimal investment. His **Elemental Skill**, *Dominus Lapidis*, has two forms. A tap summons a stone pillar that deals AoE Geo damage and resonates with other Geo structures, dealing ticking AoE damage in a small radius. However, the most important use is holding the skill, which summons the same pillar while creating a **Jade Shield**—the strongest shield in the game. This shield scales with Zhongli’s Max HP, absorbs all damage types, and reduces **all enemy resistance** to both physical and elemental damage by 20% when enemies are near it. This makes him not only a tank but also a universal buffer for your entire team’s damage output. Zhongli’s **Elemental Burst**, *Planet Befall*, summons a giant meteor that crashes down, dealing massive AoE Geo damage and **petrifying** enemies, freezing them in place for a few seconds. The burst scales off ATK, but thanks to its wide range and crowd control effect, it’s useful even without heavy investment. It’s especially good in content like Abyss, where stalling enemy movement and applying crowd control can be invaluable. Zhongli’s **constellations** further amplify his already versatile and powerful kit. **C1**, *Rock, the Backbone of Earth*, lets his pillar summon another one, increasing Geo resonance and area control—great for teams with Geo units like Albedo or Itto. **C2** grants a shield to all nearby characters when his burst is used, providing more survivability for co-op or multi-character swap teams. **C3** boosts his Skill level, improving shield strength. **C4** boosts burst damage by 20% when shielded, making his nukes even scarier. **C5** increases Burst level, and **C6** grants a 40% HP boost to nearby characters when under the Jade Shield, synergizing especially well with HP-scaling units like Hu Tao, Nilou, and Yelan. Though he’s very strong at C0, each constellation adds either defensive or offensive value that complements his role. When building Zhongli, you can go **full support**, **shield bot**, or **burst DPS**, depending on your needs. For **support builds**, the best artifact set is **4-piece Tenacity of the Millelith**, which increases shield strength and grants ATK to the team when his Skill hits enemies. It’s perfect for maximizing utility and team-wide buffs. For **burst DPS** Zhongli, you can use **2-piece Archaic Petra + 2-piece Noblesse Oblige** or even **4-piece Noblesse** to boost his ultimate. If you're going for a **hybrid** approach—decent shield and some damage—you can mix HP% with Geo DMG Bonus and Crit. In most cases, you’ll want **HP% on Sands**, **Geo DMG Bonus on the Goblet**, and **Crit Rate or Crit DMG on the Circlet**, depending on your weapon and team needs. Full HP% on all pieces is fine if you're purely building him for shields. Zhongli’s **best weapon** depends on his role. If you’re building for **shield support**, **Black Tassel** (a 3-star weapon with HP%) is shockingly effective and frees up 5-star weapons for other characters. For a **burst DPS** build, **Staff of Homa** is his best-in-slot, offering Crit DMG and HP-based bonuses that synergize with his kit. **Vortex Vanquisher** works well for shield-focused builds too, though it requires you to be shielded for the passive to work. Other solid options include **Favonius Lance** for team energy or **Deathmatch** for a balanced offensive build. Zhongli fits seamlessly into almost any team. He’s the perfect partner for **fragile hypercarries** like Ganyu, Yoimiya, Hu Tao, or Wanderer who need uninterrupted uptime to deal damage. He also excels in **Geo-centric teams** with characters like **Albedo**, **Itto**, and **Ningguang**, providing resonance and Geo structure support. Even in **reaction-based comps**, where shields aren’t always prioritized, Zhongli’s resistance shred and control make him valuable. His presence ensures comfort, allowing players to dodge less and focus more on output. In conclusion, Zhongli is a one-man fortress who protects your entire team, shreds enemy resistance, and brings great AoE and CC with his Burst. He’s insanely flexible, easy to build, and extremely powerful even at C0. Whether you use him as a defensive anchor, a burst nuker, or a hybrid of both, Zhongli elevates any team he’s in—making him one of the most universally valuable characters in Genshin Impact.

question: Tell me about Noelle
answer: Noelle is a 4-star Geo claymore user who offers a unique hybrid role—she can serve as a **healer, shielder, and main DPS**, depending on how you build her. Early on, she’s a beginner-friendly character thanks to her survivability, but with investment, Noelle becomes a powerhouse capable of dealing impressive AoE Geo damage while keeping your entire team safe and healthy. Her greatest strength is her independence—she doesn’t need specific team synergies or reactions to function, which makes her a reliable option for solo play or players with smaller rosters. Her **Elemental Skill**, *Breastplate*, creates a shield that scales with her DEF and also heals your team when she attacks enemies. The healing chance is not guaranteed unless she’s on the field, so to reliably heal, you want to keep her active during the shield’s duration. The shield also gives her solid survivability, especially when combined with Geo’s natural defensive utility. Her **Elemental Burst**, *Sweeping Time*, is where her damage shines. It converts her Normal and Charged Attacks into AoE Geo damage and scales completely off her **DEF**, not ATK. During this state, Noelle becomes a field-dominating DPS, capable of clearing large groups of enemies with massive swings of her claymore. Noelle’s **constellations** dramatically improve her performance, especially if you want to use her as a DPS. **C1**, *I Got Your Back*, ensures that her Skill’s healing always triggers when she’s on-field, making her more reliable as a healer. **C2**, *Combat Maid*, reduces her Skill cooldown when you land critical hits, helping you cycle shields and healing more frequently. **C3** raises her Skill level, strengthening the shield. **C4**, *To Be Cleaned*, restores energy when she defeats enemies during Burst, greatly improving her uptime. **C5** boosts her Burst level, increasing her core DPS skill. **C6**, *Must Be Spotless*, is a game-changer: it gives her **50% DEF to ATK conversion** during her Burst and doubles her attack speed. This transforms Noelle into a genuine carry and is the biggest power spike in her kit. With C6, she goes from a tanky support to a full-blown main DPS capable of clearing Abyss content with ease. When it comes to **artifacts**, Noelle’s best set as a DPS is **4-piece Husk of Opulent Dreams**, which gives her DEF and Geo DMG Bonus—both perfect for her kit. Before unlocking Husk, a good alternative is **2-piece Gladiator + 2-piece Husk** or **2-piece DEF% + 2-piece Archaic Petra**. If you’re playing her as a pure support or healer early on, **4-piece Maiden Beloved** or **2-piece DEF% + 2-piece Healing Bonus** can work too, though that’s not her strongest build long-term. For main stats, run **DEF% on Sands**, **Geo DMG Bonus on Goblet**, and **Crit Rate or Crit DMG on Circlet**, depending on your weapon. Substats should prioritize Crit, DEF%, and Energy Recharge for more frequent Burst uptime. Noelle’s **best weapons** for DPS are those that enhance her DEF or Crit stats. Her **best-in-slot 5-star weapon** is **Redhorn Stonethresher**, which gives Crit DMG and increases DEF-based Normal and Charged Attack damage. It's made for her. If you don't have it, 4-star options like **Serpent Spine** (Battle Pass) offer Crit Rate and consistent DPS at the cost of survivability (manageable with her shield). **Whiteblind** is the best F2P choice—it’s craftable and increases both DEF and ATK when hitting enemies, aligning perfectly with her scaling. Other options include **The Bell** (for HP/shield-focused builds) or **Favonius Greatsword** (for energy utility), though they’re more situational. Team-wise, Noelle is very **self-sufficient**, but there are ways to boost her effectiveness. For **battery support**, pair her with **Gorou**, who boosts DEF and Geo damage for other Geo characters and is especially strong in mono Geo comps. **Zhongli** is another ideal partner, offering resistance shred and the strongest shield in the game, allowing Noelle to stay in her Burst without interruption. **Albedo** can be added for additional off-field Geo DPS and resonance. Geo resonance (with two Geo units) increases shield strength and overall damage, making it a core part of many Noelle comps. If you don’t have full Geo teams, characters like **Bennett** (for ATK buffs) or **Fischl** (for energy and off-field damage) can support her well. Overall, Noelle is a powerful and flexible unit who starts out as a tanky beginner-friendly support and scales into a full-fledged DPS with investment—especially at C6. She’s one of the few characters who can heal, shield, and carry your team all in one slot, which makes her perfect for players who enjoy solo-friendly playstyles or want a durable, consistent main DPS. Whether you’re spinning claymores through waves of enemies or patching up your team mid-fight, Noelle always pulls her weight—with style and strength.

question: Tell me about Xingqiu
answer: Xingqiu is a 4-star Hydro sword user and arguably one of the most valuable characters in Genshin Impact, thanks to his incredible **off-field Hydro application**, **damage reduction**, and **healing support**. Despite his humble four-star status, Xingqiu is a staple in many top-tier teams, including some of the strongest meta comps like **National Team**, **Taser**, **Hyperbloom**, and **Hu Tao vape teams**. His versatility, low field time, and synergy with a wide range of characters make him an essential unit for both new and veteran players. The centerpiece of Xingqiu’s kit is his **Elemental Burst**, *Raincutter*. It summons Rain Swords that follow your active character and strike enemies when you perform Normal Attacks, dealing coordinated Hydro damage. These hits are fast, consistent, and perfect for triggering reactions like **Vaporize**, **Electro-Charged**, or **Bloom**. Raincutter also provides **damage reduction** and minor **healing** through the *Rain Sword* passive, making it not only offensive but also a subtle defensive tool. What makes his Burst especially powerful is that it persists when you swap characters, letting you unleash elemental reactions with whoever is on field—be it Hu Tao, Yoimiya, or Raiden Shogun. His **Elemental Skill**, *Guhua Sword: Fatal Rainscreen*, creates Rain Swords that orbit him, reduce incoming damage, and heal slightly when they break. The skill itself also deals Hydro damage in front of him and generates energy, helping you recharge his Burst more quickly. While his healing is modest, it can help in keeping your team alive in light-damage scenarios. Combined with the damage reduction and interruption resistance, it helps make squishy carries feel more comfortable during high-pressure fights. Xingqiu’s **constellations** scale his value significantly. He’s strong at **C0**, but each constellation gives him meaningful upgrades. **C1** increases the number of Rain Sword hits from his Burst, giving you even more Hydro application and reaction potential. **C2** extends the duration of his Raincutter, making it easier to keep uptime on his Hydro application during rotations. **C3** raises his Skill level, which increases his damage reduction and healing. **C4** increases Hydro RES reduction, improving his team damage against enemies. **C5** boosts his Burst level—this is huge, as it's his core skill. **C6**, one of the strongest 4-star constellations in the game, gives your active character a 50% chance to launch an extra Rain Sword strike when they Normal Attack—effectively doubling his Hydro application and making him a near-perfect enabler in reaction comps. For **artifacts**, Xingqiu’s best-in-slot set is typically **4-piece Emblem of Severed Fate**, which boosts his Energy Recharge and converts it into Bonus Burst DMG. Since his Burst is his main source of damage and it has a high cost, this set perfectly complements his strengths. If you don’t have a full Emblem set, **2-piece Noblesse + 2-piece Heart of Depth**, or **2-piece ER + 2-piece Hydro DMG** are strong alternatives. For main stats, go with **Energy Recharge or ATK% Sands** (ER is usually better), **Hydro DMG Bonus Goblet**, and **Crit Rate or Crit DMG Circlet**, depending on your weapon and substats. Substats should focus on ER (until ~180–200%), Crit, and ATK%. Weapon-wise, Xingqiu benefits most from **Energy Recharge swords** to keep his Burst ready every rotation. His best 4-star weapon is the **Sacrificial Sword**, allowing him to use his Skill twice in a row for double energy particles and damage reduction uptime. **Favonius Sword** is also excellent, especially for supporting the whole team with particle generation. For more offensive options, **Skyward Blade** is a top-tier 5-star weapon, while **Jade Cutter** and **Aquila Favonia** are viable Crit-based options. **Festering Desire** (event-exclusive) is also solid, and for pure F2P, **Skyrider Sword** or **Harbinger of Dawn** can work early on with proper ER from substats. Team-wise, Xingqiu is one of the most flexible supports in the game. He’s the Hydro backbone of **National Team** (with Bennett, Xiangling, Chongyun/Raiden), the enabler for **Hu Tao** and **Yoimiya** to trigger constant Vaporize, and a core part of **Taser comps** (with Beidou, Fischl, and Sucrose/Kazuha). He also performs excellently in **Hyperbloom** teams with Dendro and Electro characters like Nahida and Raiden, enabling fast, reactive Bloom damage. In Freeze teams, he can be used with Cryo characters like Ayaka or Rosaria, though characters like Mona may be preferred for AoE Freeze. His flexibility allows you to slot him into almost any comp that benefits from fast, single-target Hydro application. Overall, Xingqiu is an incredibly powerful and flexible character who continues to define the meta long after his release. He brings excellent value to both low-spending and high-investment players, can function at C0, and only gets better with constellations. With unmatched Hydro uptime, defensive utility, and low field time, Xingqiu remains one of the best 4-star units in the game and an irreplaceable member of many of the strongest teams in Genshin Impact.

question: Tell me about Arataki itto
answer: Arataki Itto is a 5-star Geo claymore user who serves as a powerful **main DPS**, specializing in hard-hitting, rapid-swinging **DEF-scaling Normal and Charged Attacks**. He’s the centerpiece of **mono-Geo teams** and brings an energetic, aggressive playstyle with some of the highest sustained damage in the game—when built and supported properly. Itto thrives in compositions that amplify his DEF and Geo damage, and once his rotation starts, he becomes a fast-swinging claymore machine who tears through enemies with a barrage of supercharged hits. Itto’s **Elemental Skill**, *Masatsu Zetsugi: Akaushi Burst!*, throws Ushi—a small bull that taunts enemies and deals Geo damage on impact. Ushi also **generates stacks of Superlative Superstrength** whenever he hits an enemy or when he leaves the field after taking damage. These stacks are used to perform **charged Arataki Kesagiri slashes** without consuming stamina. Each slash deals Geo damage based on Itto’s **DEF**, not ATK, which is why DEF becomes his most important stat. Ushi also generates energy, making it essential for maintaining Burst uptime. His **Elemental Burst**, *Royal Descent: Behold, Itto the Evil!*, is where the real show begins. It converts all of Itto’s Normal and Charged Attacks into Geo damage, significantly increases his **attack speed**, and boosts his **ATK based on DEF**. During this mode, he uses up his Superlative Superstrength stacks for free charged slashes. This is Itto’s highest damage window and the center of his playstyle—you want to enter Burst mode, unload as many charged slashes as possible, and then rotate back into support characters until his Burst is ready again. Arataki Itto’s **constellations** make him scale very well, though he is **fully viable at C0**. **C1**, *Stay a While and Listen Up*, increases his attack speed and lets Ushi generate an additional stack, smoothing his burst rotation. **C2**, *Gather ‘Round, It’s a Brawl!*, increases Geo resistance shred when using Charged Attacks—this is a solid DPS boost. **C3** increases his Burst talent level, directly buffing his strongest damage. **C4** reduces Ushi’s cooldown, improving uptime and energy generation. **C5** buffs his Normal Attacks. **C6**, *Arataki Itto, Present!*, gives him **100% Crit Rate** on his Charged Attacks and **adds 50% DEF scaling to each slash**, making it a massive spike in power—one of the most explosive constellations in the game for a main DPS. For **artifacts**, Itto’s best-in-slot is the **4-piece Husk of Opulent Dreams**. It gives 54% DEF and 24% Geo DMG Bonus at full stacks, and Itto can stack it easily during his rotations. The set perfectly complements his DEF-scaling kit and is always recommended for maximum performance. If you don’t have a full Husk set yet, **2-piece Husk + 2-piece Archaic Petra** is a good fallback. For main stats, go with **DEF% on Sands**, **Geo DMG Bonus on Goblet**, and **Crit Rate or Crit DMG on Circlet**, depending on your weapon and Crit ratio. Substats should prioritize Crit, DEF%, and Energy Recharge (until around 120–130%). Itto’s **best weapon** is his signature claymore, **Redhorn Stonethresher**, which gives Crit DMG and increases DEF-scaling Normal and Charged Attack damage—basically made for him. Other great 5-star options include **The Unforged** if you run him with a shielder, and **Skyward Pride** for burst uptime and a bit of team utility. Among 4-star weapons, **Serpent Spine** is excellent due to its Crit Rate and DMG buff, especially with consistent shielding. **Whiteblind** is his best F2P option—it’s craftable and increases both DEF and ATK when hitting enemies, perfectly suiting his scaling needs. In terms of team comps, Itto shines brightest in **mono-Geo teams**, especially with **Gorou**, his signature support. Gorou buffs DEF, Geo DMG, and even provides healing at C4, making him essential in full Geo teams. **Albedo** is another top-tier partner, dealing constant off-field Geo damage and generating energy with his skill. **Zhongli** adds shields and further resistance shred, allowing Itto to swing uninterrupted and hit harder. A classic and incredibly strong team would be: **Itto + Gorou + Albedo + Zhongli**. For budget or early-game teams, you can use **Noelle** as a shield support or even as a second DPS, and slot in **Geo Traveler** or **Diona** for battery/shield support if you lack Gorou or Zhongli. Overall, Arataki Itto is a stylish, satisfying, and powerful main DPS who rewards proper team building and rotation management. He brings excellent AoE Geo damage, scales very well with investment, and becomes a beast at higher constellations—but even at C0, with the right setup, he’s more than capable of clearing the hardest content in the game. If you like the feel of heavy, fast attacks and enjoy seeing huge Geo numbers flying across the screen, Itto is a blast to play and a fantastic addition to any Geo-oriented roster.

question: Tell me about Gorou
answer: Gorou is a 4-star Geo bow user who plays the unique role of a **dedicated support for DEF-scaling Geo characters**, particularly those like Arataki Itto, Noelle, and Albedo. While his usefulness may seem limited at first glance due to his niche design, he becomes an incredibly impactful character when used in the right team composition. Gorou’s playstyle revolves around amplifying the potential of his Geo teammates by offering **DEF boosts**, **Geo DMG bonuses**, and **interruption resistance**, all of which are essential for maximizing the damage output of Geo DPS units who rely on their defense stat rather than traditional ATK scaling. Gorou’s Elemental Skill, *Inuzaka All-Round Defense*, creates a banner field that provides different buffs depending on how many Geo characters are in your party. With one Geo unit, the field grants a DEF bonus. With two, it adds resistance to interruption, and with three, it grants a Geo DMG Bonus. These buffs scale dynamically with the team and remain active while the banner is on the field. This skill also generates energy particles, helping support the energy needs of heavy Burst users like Itto. His Elemental Burst, *Juuga: Forward Unto Victory*, extends these buffs in a mobile AoE field that follows the active character. It also launches periodic Geo projectiles that deal AoE damage, and the Burst’s mobile nature ensures that his team benefits from his buffs even during movement-heavy combat. While Gorou functions perfectly well at C0, his constellations elevate his role from a pure buffer to a more complete team support. His first constellation gives a flat Crit DMG boost to active Geo characters during his Burst, which directly enhances the DPS of carries like Itto or Noelle. As you unlock more constellations, his support grows deeper—particularly at C4, where he gains the ability to **heal active characters based on his DEF** while they stand in his Burst field. This addition makes Gorou capable of replacing a healer in mono Geo teams, offering sustain along with his standard buffs. His sixth constellation is especially powerful, providing a **35% DEF boost** to all nearby party members within his Burst, pushing his support potential to its peak and allowing DEF-scaling characters to reach their full damage potential. When building Gorou, you typically want to focus on **Energy Recharge** to ensure his Burst is always available, and **DEF%** to scale his healing if you’re using him at C4 or above. His best artifact set is **4-piece Noblesse Oblige**, which allows him to further increase team ATK after using his Burst. Alternatively, **The Exile** can be used for extra particle generation if you need more energy for your team. His stat priorities should lean toward ER on the Sands, DEF% on the Goblet, and either DEF% or Healing Bonus on the Circlet depending on your needs. For weapons, **Favonius Warbow** is his best 4-star option, as it helps with team-wide energy generation. If you have the 5-star **Elegy for the End**, it boosts ER and provides an additional party-wide buff when its passive triggers, making it a great pick for a fully supportive Gorou. Gorou fits best in **mono Geo teams**, where he can fully activate all his buffs and maximize the value of his kit. He’s the cornerstone of popular teams like **Itto + Albedo + Gorou + Zhongli**, where he buffs both Itto and Albedo while Zhongli provides powerful shields and further resistance shred. In this setup, Gorou not only batteries the team and boosts DEF-based damage but also heals and supports survivability if you’ve unlocked his C4. His synergy with Itto is particularly strong—he’s essentially required to unleash Itto’s full damage potential—and he also works well with Noelle in similar ways. Ultimately, Gorou is a specialized but irreplaceable support unit who makes DEF-scaling Geo teams viable and powerful. He may not be a universal buffer like Bennett or Kazuha, but within his niche, he excels beyond expectations. With his easy rotation, strong off-field presence, and game-changing constellations, Gorou becomes the perfect companion for anyone running Geo-heavy compositions, elevating them from solid to exceptional with his presence.

question: Tell me about alhaitham
answer: Alhaitham is a 5-star Dendro sword user who functions as a powerful **on-field main DPS**, dealing fast-paced Dendro damage through a unique **projection-based kit**. His gameplay revolves around weaving Normal Attacks and skill casts to generate **Chisel-Light Mirrors**, which convert his attacks into **Dendro-infused projection slashes**. These slashes hit hard, scale with Elemental Mastery (EM), and trigger frequent **Dendro reactions** like Quicken, Spread, and Aggravate when paired with Electro or Hydro teammates. Alhaitham is ideal for players who enjoy **reaction-heavy, fast-hitting melee combat** with a cerebral rotation and high payoff. His **Elemental Skill**, *Universality: An Elaboration on Form*, launches Alhaitham forward and generates one Chisel-Light Mirror (or more, depending on conditions). These mirrors float behind him and convert his Normal, Charged, and Plunging Attacks into **Dendro damage**. They also unleash **projection attacks** periodically that scale based on his EM. You can have up to **three mirrors** at once, and managing them effectively is key to maximizing his damage. Using his Skill while already holding mirrors won’t generate new ones, so **rotating properly to keep three mirrors active** during combat is an essential part of mastering his kit. His **Elemental Burst**, *Particular Field: Fetters of Phenomena*, creates a Dendro AoE field that deals multiple hits of Dendro damage. The number of hits and the energy cost depend on how many mirrors he has at the time of casting—more mirrors = more damage and lower cost. After casting the Burst, all mirrors are consumed and regenerated after a short delay, allowing you to restart his mirror cycle. While his Burst isn’t his primary source of damage, it complements his rotation well and provides big AoE Dendro output for mob fights. Alhaitham’s **constellations** enhance his kit without being necessary. **C0** is fully viable and already strong. **C1** adds more Elemental Mastery scaling and boosts reaction damage slightly. **C2** gives a chance to generate mirrors passively with Charged Attacks, which makes mirror uptime more fluid. **C4** boosts his team’s EM, offering some utility. **C6** is his biggest spike, massively increasing the number of projection attacks during mirror uptime and drastically boosting his overall DPS. However, most players will find **C0–C2** more than enough to get great value from him, especially in Spread/Aggravate teams where his base kit already excels. For **artifacts**, Alhaitham’s best-in-slot set is **4-piece Deepwood Memories**, which reduces Dendro resistance and boosts Dendro team damage. However, if another unit on your team is already holding Deepwood (like Nahida or Collei), then **4-piece Gilded Dreams** becomes his best personal damage option, increasing his EM and ATK based on team comp. His stats should focus on **Elemental Mastery**, especially if you’re building around Dendro reactions, but **ATK% Sands + Dendro DMG Goblet + Crit Circlet** is also viable if you're aiming for spread damage. Hybrid builds that combine EM and Crit stats are the most optimal for well-rounded performance. Alhaitham has several strong weapon options. His **signature 5-star sword**, *Light of Foliar Incision*, offers Crit DMG and buffs his projection attacks based on EM and Crit Rate, making it his top pick. **Primordial Jade Cutter** and **Mistsplitter Reforged** are also strong Crit-based alternatives. For 4-star weapons, **Iron Sting** is his best free-to-play option, boosting EM and reaction damage, while **Xiphos’ Moonlight** gives EM and ER scaling, helping with his Burst uptime. **The Black Sword** is another solid option if you’re leaning into a Crit-heavy build with sustained on-field time. Team-wise, Alhaitham thrives in **Quicken-Spread** or **Hyperbloom** teams. He pairs incredibly well with **Electro units** like Fischl, Kuki Shinobu, or Raiden Shogun, who can trigger Spread or Aggravate reactions while providing off-field Electro. **Nahida** is a near-perfect partner, offering massive EM and consistent Dendro application. He also works well with **Hydro characters** like Xingqiu or Yelan in Hyperbloom teams, though these comps can be a bit more chaotic to manage. For shielding and resistance reduction, **Zhongli** or **Baizhu** can provide comfort and sustain, allowing you to stay on-field safely and maximize mirror uptime. Alhaitham is a **high-skill, high-reward Dendro DPS** who rewards thoughtful rotations, mirror management, and reaction synergy. He offers a deep yet satisfying kit with impressive scaling and flexibility. With proper investment and the right teammates, Alhaitham can easily anchor a Dendro-focused team and dish out competitive damage in all types of content. If you enjoy fast swordplay, reaction-based combat, and a clever resource system, Alhaitham is a fantastic and rewarding addition to your roster.

question: Tell me about Kaveh
answer: Kaveh is a 4-star Dendro claymore user who offers a unique playstyle centered around **Bloom reactions**, AoE Dendro damage, and team utility. He stands out among Dendro units for his ability to **detonate Dendro cores** created by Bloom reactions, transforming what is usually passive damage into something proactive and visually explosive. Kaveh’s strength lies in his synergy with Hydro characters, his ability to apply Dendro consistently, and his natural compatibility with **Hyperbloom** or **pure Bloom** teams. For players who enjoy reaction-focused gameplay with flair and style, Kaveh is a fun and accessible option. Kaveh’s **Elemental Skill**, *Artistic Ingenuity*, deals AoE Dendro damage and triggers all **Dendro cores** (from Bloom reactions) within range to explode instantly. This makes him one of the few characters who can actively **control the timing of Bloom detonation**, adding an extra layer of strategy. The Skill also applies Dendro, helping maintain reaction chains when paired with Hydro units. His **Elemental Burst**, *Painted Dome*, is the heart of his kit. It enhances his Normal, Charged, and Plunging Attacks with Dendro infusion for a duration, boosts their damage based on his Elemental Mastery (EM), and causes Dendro cores to explode when they come into contact with him. During this Burst state, Kaveh becomes a true **Bloom driver**, rapidly triggering core explosions while delivering Dendro damage with each swing of his claymore.
