Childe can also be used in **Electro-Charged** or **Freeze teams**, though his Hydro uptime and AoE focus make Vaporize his best synergy overall. Childe’s best artifact set is the **Heart of Depth (4-piece)**, which boosts both Hydro damage and Normal/Charged Attacks after using a skill—perfectly aligned with his melee stance rotation. Another solid option is **2-piece Heart of Depth + 2-piece Noblesse Oblige**, or **2-piece Heart + 2-piece Gladiator/Shimenawa** for early or flexible builds. His ideal artifact stats include an **ATK% Sands**, **Hydro DMG Goblet**, and **Crit Rate or Crit DMG Circlet**, depending on weapon and sub-stat balance. Sub-stats should focus on **Crit, ATK%, and Energy Recharge**, with some **Elemental Mastery** for boosting reaction damage. When it comes to weapons, Childe’s **signature five-star bow, Polar Star**, is his best-in-slot. It offers high Crit Rate and a stacking damage bonus for skills and bursts, which perfectly complements his rotation-heavy playstyle. **Thundering Pulse** and **Aqua Simulacra** are also strong five-star options that focus on Crit and general DPS. Among four-star weapons, **The Viridescent Hunt** (Battle Pass) is excellent for Crit Rate and crowd control, while **Rust** is a top pick for increasing Normal Attack damage, especially in melee stance. **Stringless** is viable for boosting Elemental Skill and Burst damage in reaction-focused setups, although it’s less consistent than Rust. Childe’s **constellations** further enhance his damage output and flexibility. **C1** reduces his melee stance cooldown, making it easier to maintain fluid rotations. **C2** increases his Riptide effects, boosting AoE potential. **C4** provides an ATK buff when enemies are defeated, which helps in multi-wave content. His **C6** is a game-changer, removing the melee stance cooldown entirely, allowing you to stay in his most powerful form indefinitely—this turns him into a true powerhouse but is not necessary for strong performance. Even at **C0**, Childe is a top-tier DPS if played correctly. Overall, Childe is a **mechanically demanding but incredibly rewarding** character. His **stance-switching playstyle, high AoE Hydro output, and synergy with reaction teams** make him one of the most versatile and explosive damage dealers in Genshin Impact. Mastering Childe involves understanding rotation timing, energy management, and team synergy, but once you do, he can become the centerpiece of a high-damage, fast-paced team that clears content with style and efficiency.

question: Tell me about Cyno
answer: Cyno is a five-star Electro polearm user from Sumeru who fulfills the role of a **hypercarry main DPS**, specializing in sustained on-field damage through his Elemental Burst form. With his stoic, justice-driven persona and love for terrible jokes, Cyno brings a unique flair to Electro DPS characters, and his playstyle is heavily focused on maximizing uptime during his Burst window. He thrives in teams that can **feed him energy, enable fast reactions**, and allow him to stay on-field to dish out constant damage. Building and playing Cyno well revolves around **timing, reaction synergy**, and having enough support to fuel his long active time. Cyno’s **Elemental Skill, Secret Rite: Chasmic Soulfarer**, is a quick lunge that deals Electro damage. Outside his Burst, it’s a modest attack, but during his Burst state, using the Skill triggers a coordinated follow-up slash, greatly increasing its damage potential. This incentivizes you to use the Skill **repeatedly during his Burst** to maximize DPS. The cooldown is short enough to weave into combos smoothly, and the reaction potential from consistent Electro application makes it ideal for Aggravate or Hyperbloom setups. Additionally, hitting enemies with his Skill generates energy particles, which help fuel his expensive Elemental Burst. Cyno’s **Elemental Burst, Sacred Rite: Wolf’s Swiftness**, transforms him into a **stance-based melee form**, similar to Razor or Xiao. During this mode, Cyno infuses his attacks with Electro and enhances his Elemental Skill. His Normal, Charged, and Plunging Attacks are replaced with high-speed Electro strikes that scale with his stats and benefit from his Talent multipliers. The stance lasts for an extended duration, encouraging **on-field time**, and any interruptions in rotation or swapping will reduce his overall output. To get the most out of Cyno, your team must rotate quickly and allow him to stay active for the full Burst duration, roughly 18 seconds with minimal downtime. In terms of team composition, Cyno performs best in **Dendro reaction teams**, specifically **Aggravate** and **Hyperbloom**. In Aggravate teams, he’s paired with a **Dendro unit** like Nahida, Alhaitham, or the Dendro Traveler, and an **Electro support** like Fischl or Dori to provide energy and additional triggers. **Kazuha** or **Sucrose** can slot in to group enemies and offer Elemental Mastery boosts. For Hyperbloom, adding **Hydro units** like Xingqiu or Yelan can enable rapid Bloom production, and Cyno will trigger the Hyperbloom reactions with his fast-paced Electro strikes. Because Cyno needs energy to keep his Burst going every rotation, teams should be built with **multiple energy particles in mind**, often via batteries or ER gear. Cyno’s best artifact set is **Gilded Dreams (4-piece)**, which boosts his Elemental Mastery and ATK depending on the team’s elements, making it perfect for both Aggravate and Hyperbloom builds. For pure Electro damage builds, **Thundering Fury (4-piece)** is also viable, especially for reducing Skill cooldowns and increasing his reaction-based output. Alternatively, a **2-piece Thundering Fury + 2-piece EM or ATK%** combo can work for more flexible builds. Main stats should focus on **EM or ATK% Sands** (EM for reaction builds, ATK% for pure damage), **Electro DMG Bonus Goblet**, and **Crit Rate or Crit DMG Circlet**, depending on your weapon and stat balance. Sub-stats should aim for **Crit, EM, and ER**. For weapons, Cyno’s signature five-star polearm, **Staff of the Scarlet Sands**, is his best-in-slot. It provides Crit Rate and converts Elemental Mastery into ATK, synergizing perfectly with his reaction-based kit. Other strong five-star options include **Primordial Jade Winged-Spear**, **Staff of Homa**, and **Calamity Queller**, though some may require stat balancing. Among four-stars, **Deathmatch** (from the Battle Pass) and **White Tassel** (for budget Crit Rate) are solid choices. If you want to emphasize Elemental Mastery, **Moonpiercer** or **Kitain Cross Spear** can be surprisingly effective, particularly in Hyperbloom teams. Cyno’s **constellations** enhance his consistency and burst potential. **C1** allows him to gain 20% Electro DMG during his Burst, which adds a nice damage boost. **C2** improves his Energy generation and makes it easier to sustain his rotations. **C4** provides further EM boosts that synergize with his reaction builds. His **C6**, as expected, significantly boosts his damage by increasing Crit DMG and giving him extra Skill charges, making his combo rotations smoother and more explosive. While he is perfectly functional at **C0**, having **C2 or higher** makes him more fluid and comfortable to play. In summary, Cyno is a fast-paced, field-focused Electro DPS who thrives in **Dendro reaction teams** that can support his long Burst uptime. His kit rewards precision, rhythm, and synergy with off-field units that enable reactions and battery his energy needs. Though he demands tight rotations and careful team setup, the payoff is a **flashy, sustained Electro playstyle** that feels both rewarding and stylish. For players who enjoy the thrill of being constantly active on the battlefield with consistent reaction-based damage, Cyno is a highly satisfying and competitive choice.

question: Tell me about Diona
answer: Diona is a four-star Cryo bow user from Mondstadt who offers a well-rounded support role through her **healing, shielding, and Cryo application**. As the bartender of the Cat’s Tail and a spirited hater of alcohol, Diona’s quirky personality contrasts with her powerful utility on the battlefield. She’s a staple support character in many teams because of her ability to **sustain the team defensively while enabling Cryo-related reactions** like Freeze and Superconduct. Diona excels in compositions where survivability and consistent Cryo application are important, and she remains relevant even as new support characters are released. Her **Elemental Skill, Icy Paws**, is her primary defensive tool. When pressed, Diona dashes forward and fires two Cryo projectiles that generate a small shield based on her max HP. When held, she fires five projectiles, creating a stronger shield and applying Cryo more widely. The shield absorbs damage and provides 250% absorption efficiency against Cryo damage, making her a top pick for protecting characters during heavy Cryo encounters or Abyss floors filled with freezing mechanics. The shield's duration and strength scale with her HP, so building her with HP% stats greatly enhances her performance. Diona’s **Elemental Burst, Signature Mix**, tosses a special cocktail that creates a **healing field** in a small AoE. Allies within the field receive **continuous healing over time**, which also scales with Diona’s max HP. Simultaneously, the field deals **Cryo damage** to enemies inside it, making her one of the rare characters who can heal and apply an element simultaneously in a persistent area. This makes her particularly valuable in **Freeze teams** with characters like Ayaka, Ganyu, or Mona, where consistent Cryo application is key to locking enemies in place. It’s also helpful in **Superconduct teams**, reducing enemy physical resistance and enabling physical DPS units like Eula. Diona shines in teams that want both **defensive utility and Cryo synergy**. In Freeze teams, she can serve as a Cryo battery and applier while keeping the team healthy and protected. In **Physical teams**, especially those using Eula or Razor, Diona’s ability to trigger Superconduct through her skill or Burst reduces physical resistance on enemies, greatly boosting overall DPS. She can also be used effectively in **Overworld or casual co-op** play, where her shield and healing make her a reliable utility character for newer or less optimized teams. Her ranged Cryo application also lets her safely apply Cryo to targets for setting up reactions from a distance. When it comes to artifacts, Diona’s most common and effective choice is the **Noblesse Oblige (4-piece)** set, which boosts team ATK after using her Burst. Since she doesn’t rely on personal damage and uses her Burst frequently, this set maximizes her team support value. Another viable set is the **Tenacity of the Millelith (4-piece)**, especially if she’s being used for shield uptime and you want her to also buff the team’s ATK. If energy is an issue, a **2-piece Emblem of Severed Fate + 2-piece HP% or Tenacity** build can help balance healing and ER. Her ideal main stats are **HP% Sands**, **HP% Goblet**, and **Healing Bonus Circlet**, with sub-stats focused on **Energy Recharge** and more HP%. For weapons, **Favonius Warbow** is her top choice in most builds. It provides Energy Recharge and team-wide particle generation when she lands crits, which helps maintain her Burst uptime and contribute energy to other characters. **Sacrificial Bow** is also strong, allowing her to reset her Skill cooldown and generate more Cryo particles, improving shield uptime. **Recurve Bow**, though a three-star weapon, gives a massive HP boost and is a solid early-game choice for maximizing healing and shielding. **Elegy for the End**, a five-star bow, can further support reaction-based teams with its Elemental Mastery and ATK buffs, though it's a luxury option. Diona’s **constellations** significantly enhance her performance. **C1** increases her shield strength and duration, which is already helpful. **C2** reduces enemy ATK within her Burst, providing extra team protection. **C5** boosts her Burst level, increasing her healing output. But her most game-changing constellation is **C6**, which gives **Energy Recharge to characters inside her Burst zone**, helping battery characters like Eula or Ayaka maintain Burst uptime. This makes her an excellent support in energy-hungry comps and adds utility beyond healing and shielding. Overall, Diona is an extremely versatile support who provides **survivability, Cryo application, and energy utility**. Whether in Freeze, Physical, or hybrid teams, she offers consistent value with her shields and heals, while her constellations only improve her ability to serve the whole team. She’s a fantastic pick for players who want to **stabilize their team**, apply Cryo consistently, and enable powerful elemental reactions. Diona’s reliability, low investment needs, and defensive strength have made her a long-standing favorite in both the Abyss and casual play.

question: Tell me about Dori
answer: Dori is a four-star Electro claymore user from Sumeru who brings a unique blend of **healing, energy regeneration, and Electro application** to her team. With her merchant flair and an eccentric personality, Dori operates a bit differently from other Electro characters by focusing more on **support and utility** rather than raw damage. Her playstyle centers around setting up sustained energy and healing support through her Burst, making her especially useful in **energy-hungry teams** or with characters who benefit from off-field Electro application. While her mechanics may seem unconventional at first, Dori can be a valuable support in the right setups. Her **Elemental Skill, Spirit-Warding Lamp: Troubleshooter Cannon**, fires a projectile that splits upon impact, dealing AoE Electro damage and generating energy particles when it hits enemies. This is a straightforward part of her kit, but it's important for both energy generation and consistent Electro application. The Skill scales with her attack, but for most support builds, you won't focus on its damage—its real value lies in its ability to trigger reactions like Overload, Superconduct, or Electro-Charged when needed, especially with characters who apply other elements off-field. The true centerpiece of Dori’s kit is her **Elemental Burst, Alcazarzaray’s Exactitude**, which summons the **Jinni**, a magical spirit that connects to the active character via a tether. While this tether is active, the Jinni periodically **heals the active character and regenerates energy**, based on Dori’s max HP and Energy Recharge. The connection also applies Electro at intervals, enabling reactions even while you're focused on healing or other abilities. This makes Dori an excellent choice for **sustained healing and batterying**, especially for characters who struggle to maintain their Burst uptime. The Electro application is a bonus, but it can be valuable in reaction-based teams like Hyperbloom, especially in lower-pressure content or overworld exploration. In terms of team composition, Dori is a flexible support for teams that lack energy or consistent healing. She works well with **characters like Cyno, Beidou, or Yae Miko**, who need constant energy input to fuel their high-cost Bursts. In reaction-based teams, such as **Hyperbloom (Dendro + Hydro + Electro)** or **Aggravate**, she can fill the support role by applying Electro and keeping the team healthy while freeing other units to focus on damage. Dori can also pair with characters like **Raiden Shogun**, who may not need healing but benefit from additional Electro energy particles. Although her Electro application isn’t fast enough for high-end reaction spam, it’s consistent enough for most casual and mid-level teams. Dori’s **best artifact set** is typically the **Noblesse Oblige (4-piece)**, which provides a team-wide ATK buff after using her Burst, enhancing her supportive role. If used in reaction teams, a **2-piece Tenacity of the Millelith + 2-piece Maiden Beloved** or **2-piece HP% + 2-piece ER%** setup can also work depending on whether you’re focusing more on healing, survivability, or energy. For main stats, you’ll want **HP% on Sands**, **HP% or Electro DMG Bonus on the Goblet** depending on whether you're applying reactions or focusing on healing, and **Healing Bonus or HP% on the Circlet**. Sub-stats should prioritize **Energy Recharge**, **HP%**, and a bit of **Elemental Mastery** if you're helping trigger reactions. As for weapons, **Favonius Greatsword** is by far her best four-star option. It offers much-needed **Energy Recharge** and can help battery the entire team when built with enough Crit Rate to reliably trigger its passive. **Sacrificial Greatsword** is another decent choice, allowing her to reset her skill cooldown and generate more energy, although it’s less ideal than Favonius. For budget players, **The Bell** and **Forest Regalia** provide HP and ER respectively, but their passives are much less useful. If you’re aiming to maximize healing, **Katsuragikiri Nagamasa** can also work thanks to its ER stat and support-oriented passive. Dori’s **constellations** help smooth out her support mechanics. At **C1**, she reduces the cooldown of her Skill when Electro reactions are triggered—nice for teams relying on reactions. **C2** makes her Burst easier to use by increasing the duration of the tether and improving her healing efficiency. **C4** boosts her energy generation for the team, and **C6** adds an Elemental Mastery buff for the active character, which is great in Dendro reaction comps like Hyperbloom or Aggravate. Even at **C0**, Dori functions well enough as a healer and battery, though constellations can enhance her synergy with elemental teams. Overall, Dori may not be the first Electro character that comes to mind when building a reaction-heavy or high-damage team, but she offers **excellent value in energy regeneration and healing**, particularly for teams that need sustainability over burst damage. Her kit rewards creative playstyles and shines in teams where survivability and uptime are key concerns. With the right investment and team pairing, Dori can be a surprisingly effective support character who keeps the team powered and healthy while adding a touch of Electro flair.

question: Tell me about Faruzan
answer: Faruzan is a four-star Anemo bow user from Sumeru who serves as a powerful **Anemo support**, specifically designed to enhance the performance of **Anemo DPS characters** like Xiao, Wanderer (Scaramouche), and Heizou. While her personality as a quirky, time-displaced scholar adds flavor and charm, her gameplay centers around **providing Anemo RES shred, Anemo damage buffs, and crowd control**, making her an essential piece in teams that rely on strong Anemo-based damage. Though she requires investment and careful energy management, Faruzan can drastically increase the potential of any Anemo DPS once she is properly built and supported. Her **Elemental Skill, Wind Realm of Nasamjnin**, fires a small Anemo projectile that creates a pressurized collapse, pulling enemies together in a short-range vortex. This crowd control function is similar to Sucrose or Venti’s Skill, but on a smaller scale. After using her Skill, Faruzan enters a “Manifest Gale” state, which turns her next aimed shot into a special **Hurricane Arrow**. This charged shot applies her key Anemo debuff to enemies and is required to activate her support mechanics. Although the setup requires more effort than other supports, it's worth it, especially when building around Anemo carries. Her **Elemental Burst, The Wind’s Secret Ways**, is where Faruzan’s true support potential is unlocked. It creates a Dazzling Polyhedron that moves in a triangle pattern, intermittently inflicting AoE Anemo damage and applying **Anemo RES reduction** to enemies while **buffing Anemo DMG** for her teammates. This is an extremely rare and valuable support effect, especially because it stacks multiplicatively with other damage sources and buffs. Her Burst allows Anemo characters to reach new damage ceilings, making her irreplaceable in mono-Anemo or plunge-focused teams like Xiao’s. Team-wise, Faruzan is best when **paired with strong Anemo DPS units**, particularly **Xiao**, who relies on external Anemo buffs and resistance shred to reach his full potential. With Faruzan’s buffs, Xiao’s plunge damage gets a massive boost. Similarly, she pairs wonderfully with **Wanderer**, who benefits from her Anemo DMG buffs and grouping capabilities. In teams with **Heizou**, she also provides crowd control and damage amplification. Since Faruzan’s buffs are specific to Anemo damage, she doesn't provide much value outside of Anemo-focused comps, and so she’s not a general support for all team types. However, within her niche, she is arguably the best. Energy recharge is a critical part of Faruzan’s build, as her Burst is quite costly at **80 energy**, and her personal particle generation is low. Because of this, she usually needs an **Energy Recharge Sands**, an **ER-focused weapon**, or a **battery teammate** to consistently cast her Burst every rotation. When she has enough ER, her buffs can be applied seamlessly in short rotations, dramatically improving team performance. It’s often helpful to run her with another Anemo unit like Jean or Sucrose to generate energy for her. For artifacts, Faruzan typically uses the **Noblesse Oblige (4-piece)** set to provide an ATK buff to the team after her Burst and increase her Burst damage, or she can use **The Exile (4-piece)** for added energy regeneration in more supportive builds. Some players also run a **2-piece Viridescent Venerer + 2-piece Emblem of Severed Fate** setup to balance Anemo DMG and ER. Main stats should focus on **Energy Recharge Sands**, **Anemo DMG Bonus Goblet**, and **Crit Rate or Crit DMG Circlet** if you’re trying to scale her personal damage slightly, but ER and HP/utility stats are often preferred if she’s played purely for support. Sub-stats should always prioritize Energy Recharge until her Burst is comfortably up every rotation. For weapons, Faruzan benefits most from **Energy Recharge bows**, especially if she's at low constellation levels. **Favonius Warbow** is a fantastic option, as it generates extra particles for the whole team. **Elegy for the End**, a five-star bow, is also excellent—it not only gives her ER but adds a team-wide EM and ATK buff that fits nicely into most Anemo-centric teams. **Sacrificial Bow** can also be decent to allow more frequent Skill usage, but the extra Hurricane Arrows are rarely needed once her Burst is up reliably. Faruzan’s **constellations** significantly improve her quality of life and support performance. At **C2**, she gains more energy regeneration, which directly fixes part of her biggest flaw. **C4** increases the duration of her debuffs, allowing for smoother team rotations. Her **C6** is transformative—it provides **massive Crit DMG bonuses for Anemo characters**, turning her into a true enabler for top-tier damage output. While she can function at **C0** with heavy energy investment, she becomes significantly more comfortable to use at **C2+**, and at **C6**, she’s one of the best Anemo buffers in the game. In summary, Faruzan is a specialized, high-value support unit designed for Anemo main DPS characters. With the ability to shred Anemo resistance, increase Anemo damage, and provide mild crowd control, she transforms characters like Xiao and Wanderer from good to great. While she has notable energy issues that must be managed and a bit of setup with her skill rotation, the payoff is immense. For players who enjoy investing in Anemo-centric teams and want to see their favorite Anemo carries reach their full potential, Faruzan is not just useful—she’s essential.

question: Tell me about Furina
answer: Furina is a five-star Hydro sword user from Fontaine and serves as both an elegant performer and a powerful off-field support or sub-DPS with unique mechanics that revolve around **HP fluctuations** in the team. As the Hydro Archon, Furina brings a flamboyant and theatrical flair to combat, making her playstyle not only distinct in theme but also in function. Unlike most Hydro units who specialize in healing or Hydro application, Furina’s strength lies in her ability to **convert HP changes into damage** and team-wide buffs, making her one of the most versatile and impactful supports in Genshin Impact. Her kit scales primarily with **max HP and team HP changes**, rewarding players who can balance healing and HP loss in creative ways. Furina’s **Elemental Skill, Salon Solitaire**, switches between two modes depending on whether your team is above or below 50% HP. When her team is healthy, she summons three little spirits called the Salon Members—Gentilhomme, Surintendante, and Mademoiselle—that attack enemies with coordinated Hydro strikes, dealing off-field damage over time and enabling Hydro-related reactions like Vaporize or Bloom. When the active character’s HP is below 50%, these spirits instead cheer and consume HP from your team to boost their damage output. This dynamic shift allows Furina to scale her own damage while also creating synergy with healers who can restore lost HP efficiently. This dance of draining and restoring HP is the core rhythm of her gameplay. Her **Elemental Burst, Let the People Rejoice**, transforms her into a powerful buffer. Upon use, Furina enters a state where she provides a flat **damage bonus to the entire team** based on how much the HP of team members has changed (both healed and lost) over a short period. The more HP fluctuation occurs during this window, the stronger the bonus becomes. This makes her an incredible enabler for characters who deal high damage over time or burst within a short rotation window. Since her Burst benefits from HP changes rather than just loss or gain, Furina works best in teams where HP is actively being drained and restored, whether by her own skill, characters with HP costs, or consistent healers. Furina is most impactful when paired with **strong healers** or **HP-interactive characters**. Units like **Baizhu, Kokomi, Jean, or Charlotte** provide the healing needed to sustain the HP loss Furina generates and maintain uptime on her buffs. Characters like **Neuvillette**, who convert HP loss into damage, also synergize beautifully with Furina since her kit can fuel his mechanics while he restores HP himself. In hypercarry setups, Furina acts as both an off-field Hydro applier and a damage amplifier, supporting main DPS units like **Navia, Ayaka, or Alhaitham** with buffs that scale quickly once the right team conditions are met. Her ability to boost the entire team's output makes her one of the most flexible support characters, whether in mono-Hydro, reaction, or mixed-element teams. For artifacts, Furina’s best-in-slot is the **Golden Troupe (4-piece)**, which dramatically boosts her off-field Elemental Skill damage, especially when she’s not on the field. This set fully capitalizes on her Salon Members’ Hydro attacks and maximizes her supportive damage contribution. However, if you’re using her more for her buffing potential than damage, a **2-piece Tenacity of the Millelith + 2-piece HP% set** or **2-piece Emblem of Severed Fate + HP%** can be used to increase Burst uptime and buff strength. Main stats should prioritize **HP% Sands**, **Hydro DMG Bonus Goblet**, and **Crit Rate or Crit DMG Circlet** (if you're scaling her personal damage), or more HP% if focusing purely on her support role. Sub-stats should aim for HP%, Energy Recharge, and Crit stats. When it comes to weapons, Furina’s signature sword, **Splendor of Tranquil Waters**, is her best option, providing Crit DMG and a passive that enhances her damage and buffing based on HP fluctuation—perfectly designed for her kit. Among five-star alternatives, **Primordial Jade Cutter** works well thanks to its Crit Rate and HP synergy. For four-star weapons, **Festering Desire** boosts her Elemental Skill damage and Energy Recharge, while **Favonius Sword** helps ensure her Burst is always ready, especially in energy-hungry comps. **Sacrificial Sword** can be a decent budget pick if you want more Skill uptime, though she doesn’t benefit as much from Skill resets as other sword users. Furina’s **constellations** significantly enhance her performance, especially if you're using her in high-end content. **C1** removes the HP condition from her skill, allowing both modes to function simultaneously and improving overall consistency. **C2** increases her HP and boosts her damage even further. **C4** enhances her healing and buffs when HP is restored, while **C6** is an absolute game-changer—it grants her the ability to provide massive team-wide buffs and adds a huge personal damage bonus, turning her into a quasi-DPS in her own right. Still, she is already incredibly powerful at **C0**, and most players will find that she performs beautifully without needing constellations. Overall, Furina is a brilliantly designed and thematically rich character who redefines what a Hydro support can be. She combines elegant off-field damage, HP-based buffing, and team-wide synergy into a seamless kit that rewards strategic play and thoughtful team building. Whether you’re weaving her into reaction-based teams or building around HP fluctuation mechanics, Furina elevates both damage and aesthetic flair to a new level. For players who enjoy dynamic support roles, flexible Hydro application, and watching the battlefield shift like a theatrical performance, Furina is easily one of the most compelling and valuable units in Genshin Impact.

question: Tell me about Ganyu
answer: Ganyu is a five-star Cryo bow user from Liyue who stands as one of the most powerful and versatile DPS units in Genshin Impact. Known for her serene personality and hardworking nature as the secretary to the Liyue Qixing, Ganyu’s combat style is elegant, deliberate, and incredibly effective. Her true strength lies in her **charged attacks**, which unleash devastating AoE Cryo damage that can wipe out enemies from a safe distance. Whether built as a freeze-based support or a main DPS, Ganyu offers consistent, high-damage output with minimal cooldown downtime, making her an exceptional choice for players who value precision and sustained performance. Ganyu’s playstyle revolves around her **Charged Attack: Frostflake Arrow**, which, after a brief wind-up, fires a powerful Cryo arrow that explodes on impact, dealing AoE Cryo damage. This is her primary source of damage in a typical DPS build. The Frostflake Arrow scales exceptionally well with both attack and Crit stats, and its AoE effect allows her to deal with both single-target enemies and clustered mobs effectively. Ganyu’s damage ramps up when she strings together a series of these charged shots, especially when supported by a team that keeps enemies frozen or distracted, allowing her to snipe safely from a distance without interruption. Her **Elemental Skill, Trail of the Qilin**, leaves behind a lotus that taunts enemies and explodes after a short time, dealing AoE Cryo damage. This ability functions both as a distraction and a source of energy, creating breathing room for Ganyu to charge her Frostflake Arrows without being interrupted. It’s also a helpful tool for managing aggro during difficult fights or crowd control situations. Her **Elemental Burst, Celestial Shower**, summons a Cryo storm that rains down icicles over a wide area, applying constant Cryo damage to enemies within its radius. This is especially powerful in **Freeze teams**, where enemies can be immobilized under the storm, making it one of the most effective area denial tools in the game. Team-wise, Ganyu shines in both **Freeze** and **Melt** comps. In Freeze teams, pairing her with Hydro characters like **Mona, Kokomi, or Xingqiu** allows her to keep enemies locked in place while she safely unloads her Frostflake Arrows. **Venti** or **Kazuha** can group enemies together and provide Cryo resistance shred via the Viridescent Venerer set, which greatly boosts her overall damage. This setup is extremely effective in Spiral Abyss, where crowd control and sustained AoE damage dominate. Alternatively, Ganyu can be played in **Melt comps**, where characters like **Bennett and Xiangling** provide Pyro application to trigger high-damage Melt reactions from her arrows. Melt Ganyu offers significantly higher burst potential but requires more positioning and reaction timing compared to Freeze teams. For artifacts, Ganyu’s best-in-slot set is **Wanderer’s Troupe (4-piece)**, which boosts her Charged Attack damage and Elemental Mastery—perfect for amplifying both raw Cryo damage and Melt reaction damage. In Freeze comps where EM isn’t as critical, **Blizzard Strayer (4-piece)** is exceptional, granting Crit Rate against frozen enemies and additional Cryo DMG Bonus. It also synergizes beautifully with Cryo resonance and makes Crit stat management much easier. As for main stats, focus on **ATK% Sands**, **Cryo DMG Bonus Goblet**, and **Crit DMG or Crit Rate Circlet**, depending on weapon and set choices. Sub-stats should target Crit stats, ATK%, and Elemental Mastery if using Melt builds. Ganyu’s best weapons vary slightly depending on build, but **Amos’ Bow** is her undisputed best-in-slot for general use, enhancing both normal and charged attacks significantly the longer the arrow travels, which synergizes perfectly with her Frostflake Arrows. Other five-star options like **Aqua Simulacra** or **Polar Star** offer high Crit stats and damage buffs that also work well. Among four-star bows, **Prototype Crescent** (craftable) is surprisingly strong when used correctly—if you hit a weak spot, it grants a large ATK buff. **Hamayumi** is another strong free-to-play option that boosts charged attack damage when Ganyu’s energy is full, making it a natural fit for her playstyle. Ganyu is already incredible at **C0**, but her **constellations** further refine her potential. **C1** gives her an extra Frostflake Arrow without needing to charge again, which is a nice quality-of-life improvement. **C2** boosts energy generation and allows her Burst to support the team more effectively. **C4** and **C6** are significant spikes, with C6 drastically reducing enemy Cryo resistance and enabling her to fire arrows without charge time, which turns her into a rapid-fire machine gun of Cryo damage. However, she doesn’t rely on constellations to excel—her power is readily accessible even at base level with proper investment. In conclusion, Ganyu is a top-tier Cryo DPS with a graceful yet deadly playstyle centered around precision and high damage per shot. Whether you prefer locking enemies down with constant Freeze or pushing out massive Melt numbers, Ganyu adapts beautifully to both styles. She’s a long-range powerhouse who rewards patient, accurate players and provides immense value in both open-world and high-end content like the Abyss. If you’re looking for a main DPS that combines elegance, control, and overwhelming Cryo damage, Ganyu is one of the strongest and most rewarding characters in the game.

question: Tell me about Keqing
answer: Keqing is a five-star Electro sword user from Liyue who excels as a fast-paced, precision-based main DPS, offering a highly agile and responsive combat style. She’s known for her quick strikes, rapid repositioning, and elegant swordplay, with a kit that rewards players who enjoy speed and versatility in combat. While she was often considered underwhelming compared to other top-tier DPS units in the early days of Genshin, the introduction of **Dendro reactions**, especially **Aggravate**, has revitalized her performance and secured her a place in powerful team comps. Whether you build her as a traditional Electro DPS or opt into physical or hybrid builds, Keqing brings fluid mechanics and flashy mobility that make her a fun and stylish character to master. Her **Elemental Skill, Stellar Restoration**, is the heart of her identity. It allows her to throw a Lightning Stiletto that can either deal AoE Electro damage on impact or teleport her to the mark when pressed again, triggering an additional AoE Electro slash. This teleportation gives Keqing unmatched battlefield mobility, letting her dodge attacks, reposition mid-combo, or chase down enemies instantly. If the Skill is followed up by a Charged Attack instead of teleporting, it also converts the damage into Electro, enabling her to continuously apply Electro for reaction setups. This gives her flexibility in how she plays, and at higher skill levels, good Keqing players weave their combos to flow smoothly between teleportation and charged strikes. Her **Elemental Burst, Starward Sword**, delivers a quick series of Electro slashes in a wide AoE followed by a finishing strike. It scales off her ATK and deals consistent Electro damage, making it a solid burst tool to clear mobs or chunk down elite enemies. While her Burst isn’t the flashiest in terms of multipliers, it has a low energy cost and short animation, allowing her to get back into the fight quickly. It fits perfectly into her playstyle, where she cycles between quick rotations of skill, normal attacks, and bursts without breaking momentum. In terms of team building, Keqing now finds a powerful niche in **Aggravate teams**, where Electro is amplified by Dendro. Pairing her with Dendro applicators like **Nahida, Baizhu, Yaoyao, or Collei** opens up access to high-frequency, high-scaling Aggravate procs that elevate her damage significantly. Add an Electro support like **Fischl** or **Kuki Shinobu** for additional energy and Electro particles, and you've got a well-rounded team that enables Keqing to stay on-field and dish out non-stop reactions. Alternatively, she can still function in **Electro-Charged** or **mono-Electro teams** with units like Yae Miko and Beidou, although those comps are a bit less optimal in today’s meta. Some players even opt for **physical Keqing** with Cryo supports like Rosaria and superconduct setups, though that route has generally fallen out of favor compared to her Dendro synergy. Keqing’s best artifact set in Aggravate-focused builds is **Thundering Fury (4-piece)**, which increases Aggravate damage and reduces her Skill cooldown, letting her use Stellar Restoration more often for higher uptime and damage. Alternatively, **Gilded Dreams (4-piece)** is strong if you're focusing more on Elemental Mastery scaling and triggering reactions. For a more general Electro build, **2-piece Thundering Fury + 2-piece Gladiator’s Finale** or **Shimenawa’s Reminiscence** also works. Main stats should focus on **ATK% or Elemental Mastery Sands**, **Electro DMG Goblet**, and **Crit Rate/Crit DMG Circlet**, depending on your weapon and stat balance. Sub-stats should prioritize Crit Rate, Crit Damage, EM (for Aggravate builds), and ATK%. Weapon-wise, Keqing’s best-in-slot is **Mistsplitter Reforged**, which offers Crit DMG and Elemental DMG bonuses that perfectly match her fast-paced Electro playstyle. Other excellent five-star swords include **Primordial Jade Cutter** for a Crit Rate boost and HP scaling, or **Haran Geppaku Futsu** if you’re focusing on normal attack damage. For four-star options, **Lion’s Roar** is fantastic in Electro-Charged or Aggravate teams, providing a strong damage bonus against Electro-affected enemies. **Black Sword** is another solid pick, especially if you're going the Crit-heavy route, and **Iron Sting** is a solid free-to-play option that increases Elemental Mastery for reaction-focused builds. Keqing’s constellations offer incremental improvements but aren’t necessary for her to be effective. **C1** increases her Energy Recharge, making her Burst more consistent. **C2** and **C4** provide more attack bonuses and survivability. Her biggest spike comes at **C6**, where her Electro-infused attacks get a 6-second damage boost after using her Skill, allowing her to dish out sustained high damage in longer fights. However, she performs well even at C0—especially in Aggravate teams—and doesn’t require constellations to be strong. In summary, Keqing is a stylish and dynamic Electro DPS who thrives in fast-paced, reaction-heavy teams. Her unique blend of teleportation, rapid attacks, and elemental flexibility makes her incredibly engaging to play. While she was once seen as a flashy but underwhelming unit, the rise of Dendro and Aggravate has given her a second life in the meta. For players who enjoy quick decision-making, rapid rotations, and elegant swordplay, Keqing is one of the most satisfying characters to build and master in Genshin Impact.

question: Tell me about Klee
answer: Klee is a five-star Pyro catalyst user from Mondstadt who brings a unique, explosive playstyle that blends high single-target damage with chaotic AoE bursts. Known for her childlike innocence and destructive tendencies, Klee is a high-risk, high-reward character who demands a bit of mechanical finesse but rewards players with incredible Pyro damage potential when used properly. Unlike more straightforward DPS units, Klee’s kit involves a rhythm of timed Normal Attacks, careful stamina management, and smart use of her skill and burst to keep enemies juggled and burning. She shines as a **main on-field Pyro DPS**, and her kit scales primarily with her ATK and Pyro DMG, making her build fairly straightforward but execution-dependent. Klee’s Normal Attack throws bouncing bombs that deal Pyro damage, and every third attack releases a charged mine that explodes shortly after contact. These attacks form the core of her playstyle and are deceptively powerful, especially when animation-cancelled efficiently. Her **Elemental Skill, Jumpy Dumpty**, throws a bouncing bomb that bounces three times and splits into mines on impact. These mines persist for a few seconds before exploding, allowing you to set traps or trigger chain reactions. It’s her main source of energy generation and can be used both offensively and tactically to control space. Smart players will learn to throw Jumpy Dumpties just ahead of groups of enemies to capitalize on both the bounce damage and mine detonation. Klee’s **Elemental Burst, Sparks ‘n’ Splash**, summons a barrage of homing Pyro sparks that attack nearby enemies automatically while she remains on-field. It’s an incredible source of consistent Pyro application and passive damage that complements her fast-paced fighting style. However, the burst is canceled if she leaves the field, so timing is crucial—ideally, you want to use it when you're ready to commit to her for a full rotation. This creates a very “sticky” DPS loop: once you pop her Burst, you’ll want to stay on Klee until it's done to maximize damage. Her passive talents also support her kit well, with bonuses to Charged Attack Crit Rate and energy regeneration when triggering Pyro reactions, making her an excellent enabler for overload, vaporize, and melt-based teams. Klee fits best in **reaction-focused teams** that can capitalize on her rapid Pyro application. For Vaporize setups, Hydro appliers like Xingqiu, Yelan, or Kokomi are ideal—they allow her to consistently trigger Vaporize with her Normal and Charged Attacks for huge damage. For Overload or Aggravate-style comps, Electro supports like Fischl, Beidou, or Raiden can add energy and damage while helping keep enemies staggered. Klee can also work in mono-Pyro or Melt teams with support from Bennett, Xiangling, and Rosaria, depending on what role you want her to fill. However, she benefits greatly from **shields and healing**, since her short range and squishy nature make her vulnerable during combat—shielders like Zhongli or healers like Bennett/Kokomi help keep her alive and on-field longer. For artifacts, Klee’s best-in-slot is **Crimson Witch of Flames** (4-piece), which enhances both her Pyro DMG and reaction damage, especially Vaporize and Overload. It complements her kit perfectly and scales extremely well with reaction-based gameplay. If you’re still farming or experimenting, a 2-piece combination of Crimson Witch and either Gladiator’s Finale or Shimenawa’s Reminiscence (for extra ATK%) can work as a placeholder. Main stats should focus on **ATK% or Energy Recharge Sands**, **Pyro DMG Goblet**, and **Crit Rate or Crit DMG Circlet**, depending on her weapon and your sub-stat balance. Sub-stats should prioritize Crit, ATK%, and some Energy Recharge for smoother burst uptime. Weapon-wise, Klee has a few excellent choices. Her signature five-star weapon, **Lost Prayer to the Sacred Winds**, is an amazing fit for her—offering high Crit Rate, elemental damage scaling, and a passive that rewards staying on-field, which synergizes with her burst and DPS playstyle. **The Widsith** is a phenomenal four-star option, giving huge random buffs to either ATK, Elemental DMG, or Elemental Mastery, all of which benefit her kit. **Solar Pearl** is another good four-star catalyst for Battle Pass users, offering balanced Crit Rate and decent scaling for both Normal Attacks and Elemental Skills. For a more budget option, **Mappa Mare** is a craftable catalyst that increases elemental damage after triggering reactions and can be solid early on. Her constellations are strong, though not necessary to enjoy her. **C1** reduces the cooldown of her Elemental Skill, giving her more consistent energy and mine usage, while **C2** boosts her energy regeneration and Crit Rate. **C4** offers defensive utility by reducing enemy DEF, and **C6** is an enormous spike in power, granting her a guaranteed crit after using her Burst and significantly amping up her reaction potential. While she functions well at C0, each constellation noticeably smooths out her rotations and raises her ceiling, especially if you want to use her in Spiral Abyss or harder content. In summary, Klee is a powerful, high-octane Pyro DPS who rewards aggressive, smart play with a blend of AoE and single-target destruction. Her kit is both playful and precise, making her ideal for players who enjoy mastering a character’s rhythm and using positioning and timing to deal massive damage. While she can feel a bit squishy or chaotic in the hands of beginners, players who stick with her and learn to optimize her burst windows, reactions, and animation cancels will find one of the most explosive and satisfying damage dealers in Genshin Impact.

question: Tell me about Sara
answer: Kujou Sara is a four-star Electro bow user from Inazuma, serving as both an Electro support and buffer with a militaristic, no-nonsense demeanor that reflects her role as a general of the Tenryou Commission. While she’s often compared to Bennett for her buffing utility, Sara’s playstyle and niche are quite distinct. She shines best when built and played specifically to **amplify the burst damage of Electro characters**, particularly those who rely on attack scaling. Her unique role as a buffer and Electro enabler makes her a valuable asset in specific team comps, especially with characters like Raiden Shogun, Yae Miko, or even Fischl when used in burst-oriented setups. Sara’s playstyle revolves heavily around her **Elemental Skill, Tengu Stormcall**, which grants a **Crowfeather buff** to her next charged shot. When this charged shot hits an enemy, it creates an AoE explosion that not only deals Electro damage but also grants an **Attack Bonus** to characters within its area, scaling with Sara’s base attack. The trick to playing Sara effectively is to quickly use her skill, fire a charged shot to deploy the Crowfeather, and then immediately switch to your main DPS to receive the buff and strike while it's active. Timing and placement are key, as the buff only lasts for a few seconds and affects characters who are inside the area of the feather’s explosion when it lands. Her **Elemental Burst, Subjugation: Koukou Sendou**, calls down a massive bolt of lightning in a wide AoE, dealing Electro damage and applying the Crowfeather Attack Bonus to characters caught in the field. This makes her Burst an excellent tool for **teamwide buffing**, especially when it overlaps with the DPS's own burst rotations. At higher constellations, particularly **C2 and C6**, her burst becomes much more potent—adding extra bolts of lightning and enhancing Electro Crit Damage for allies, which turns her into a core part of some of the strongest Raiden or Yae Miko teams. Without those constellations, she’s still effective, but requires more careful rotation management to maximize her contribution. Sara fits best into **Electro-centric teams** where she can support a strong Electro DPS or sub-DPS. The most notable synergy is with **Raiden Shogun**, as Sara’s Attack Buff greatly enhances Raiden’s Burst damage, especially when both are at higher constellations. Other strong partners include **Yae Miko**, who benefits from the additional Attack and Electro Crit Damage at C6, and **Keqing**, who can capitalize on the buffed Electro hits. While she can technically buff non-Electro characters, her kit and constellations are clearly designed to support Electro damage specifically, so her optimal use case lies within teams that lean heavily into the Electro element. Adding a **battery like Fischl** or a **shield/healer like Zhongli or Kokomi** can also help cover her weaknesses and ensure smooth rotations. In terms of artifacts, Sara performs best with the **Noblesse Oblige** set, as it boosts her Burst damage and provides a teamwide Attack buff after using her Burst—stacking with her existing buffs. This helps her offer even more support value in short, burst-focused rotations. Alternatively, if you’re using her mostly for her skill buffs, you could consider a **2-piece combination of Emblem of Severed Fate and Noblesse** for energy and burst effectiveness. For main stats, focus on **Energy Recharge on Sands**, **Electro Damage Bonus on Goblet**, and **Crit Rate or Crit Damage on Circlet** to allow her to deal some respectable personal damage while maintaining her support role. Sub-stats should prioritize Energy Recharge (as her Burst is relatively expensive), Crit stats, and maybe some flat ATK to buff her output. Weapon-wise, Sara benefits most from bows that boost her **base attack**, since her Attack Bonus scales directly off of that. **Skyward Harp** is one of her best 5-star options, giving both a high base ATK and Crit stats. Among four-star bows, **Alley Hunter** and **Sacrificial Bow** are strong picks, the former boosting her damage while the latter gives her a second skill use to ease energy issues. **Favonius Warbow** is a great energy-supportive choice that also provides particles for the team, especially if your Sara isn’t at high constellations and you need her Burst on cooldown. Her constellations make a huge difference. While **C1 and C2** improve her energy and burst consistency, **C6 is a massive power spike**—granting **Electro Crit Damage to all allies** within her buff zone, effectively supercharging any Electro DPS’s burst potential. This makes her one of the best supports for Raiden at C6, but even at **C2**, she’s already significantly better at her job and feels smoother to play. Overall, Kujou Sara is a specialized but extremely potent buffer for Electro damage dealers. She takes a bit of mechanical understanding and practice to play well, especially in terms of positioning and timing, but when executed properly, she can skyrocket your Electro DPS’s damage to new heights. If you’re investing in an Electro-heavy team, particularly one centered around Raiden or Yae, Sara is not just a good addition—she’s one of the best possible supports for enabling their full potential.

question: Tell me about Mualani
answer: Mualani is a five-star Hydro catalyst user from Natlan who brings a refreshing, high-energy playstyle centered around mobility and powerful HP-scaling damage. Unlike many catalyst users who focus on long-range elemental application or off-field support, Mualani is designed to be a full-on **on-field DPS**, surfing atop her shark companion, Sharky, and tearing through enemies with flashy, water-powered strikes. Her kit rewards players who enjoy fast-paced, agile combat with a focus on weaving skill-based mechanics and managing momentum for explosive payoff. She’s especially well-suited to players who want to ride the wave—literally and figuratively—while bringing heavy AoE damage and a fun, animated combat style. Her Elemental Skill, *Surfshark Wavebreaker*, is the core of her gameplay. When activated, Mualani hops onto Sharky and begins surfing around the battlefield. While riding Sharky, her Normal Attacks are transformed into Hydro-infused melee strikes called Sharky’s Bites. Each bite applies a Marked as Prey debuff to enemies and builds stacks of Wave Momentum. Once she reaches three stacks, her next attack is upgraded to a *Surging Bite*, a high-damage Hydro slash that not only deals AoE damage but also sends out homing Shark Missiles to any marked enemies nearby. This creates a highly interactive loop of mobility, positioning, and burst windows that encourages the player to stay engaged and constantly moving. Her Skill also gives her interruption resistance, but it’s not perfect—players should be mindful of strong hits that could knock her off Sharky mid-combo. Her Elemental Burst, *Boomsharka-laka*, is an explosive AoE Hydro attack that deals massive damage in a wide radius and spawns Sourcewater Droplets—essential for keeping her momentum going. The Burst scales with her Max HP, like her other abilities, and benefits greatly from her built-up momentum and enemy marks. It’s particularly effective for clearing grouped mobs or taking a big chunk out of tougher enemies after setting up with her Skill. Mualani’s passive talents help her maintain this momentum by increasing her energy regeneration and damage based on Wave Momentum and Prey Marks, making her rotations feel fluid and rewarding once you get the hang of her flow. When it comes to teams, Mualani thrives in compositions that can **protect her during Sharky’s ride** and enable reactions to boost her damage. Shielders like Zhongli or Baizhu are incredibly helpful for preventing interruptions, which is crucial for maintaining her momentum. Off-field Pyro or Electro characters like Fischl, Xiangling, or even Yae Miko allow her to trigger Vaporize or Electro-Charged reactions, increasing her damage significantly. She also benefits from Hydro Resonance, which increases Max HP—a direct buff to all her damage. Pairing her with characters like Kokomi or Furina not only boosts resonance but can also bring off-field healing or buffing that keeps her uptime high and her rotation smooth. For artifacts, Mualani’s best-in-slot set is **Marechaussee Hunter**, which boosts her Normal and Charged Attack damage while giving her a Crit Rate increase when her HP changes—a condition she triggers naturally through her playstyle. This set perfectly matches her kit and makes her DPS much more consistent. If you’re still farming or want a placeholder, a mix of HP% and Hydro DMG bonus sets like **Tenacity of the Millelith** and **Heart of Depth** can be viable. Main stats should focus on **HP% on Sands**, **Hydro Damage Bonus on Goblet**, and **Crit Rate or Crit Damage on Circlet**, depending on your weapon and sub-stat balance. Sub-stats should prioritize HP%, Crit stats, and a touch of Energy Recharge for smoother Burst access. Mualani’s best weapon is her signature five-star catalyst, **Flowing Purity**, which gives her HP% and passive effects that boost her skill and burst damage. It’s tailor-made for her and amplifies her core mechanics seamlessly. Among four-star options, **Prototype Amber** is a decent free-to-play alternative that boosts HP% and energy regeneration, though it lacks offensive potential. **The Widsith** is also surprisingly strong for short-term damage spikes, especially if the buff lines up with her burst window. For players on a budget or just starting, **Thrilling Tales of Dragon Slayers** can provide situational value if she’s paired with a stronger main carry. Her constellations enhance her power and playstyle without making her feel dependent on them. Her **C1** improves her ability to maintain Wave Momentum and slightly boosts her damage output. **C2** reduces cooldowns, letting her spend more time surfing and less time waiting. The real jump comes at **C4**, where her Surging Bites deal even more AoE damage and spawn additional Shark Missiles. Finally, **C6** gives her a full rotation buff, turning her into a near-unstoppable Hydro force with greatly enhanced damage and sustain. While she’s completely viable and fun at C0, her constellations definitely scale her up into higher-end content more comfortably. In short, Mualani is a stylish, surfing DPS with an active playstyle that blends mobility, Hydro damage, and AoE destruction into a fluid and satisfying loop. She’s a great fit for players who enjoy characters with rhythm and tempo, and she brings something new and fun to the Hydro DPS archetype. With the right team and a bit of practice, she becomes an unstoppable wave of destruction—both beautiful and dangerous in equal measure.

question: Tell me about Neuvillette
answer: Neuvillette is a five-star Hydro catalyst user from Fontaine, and he stands out as a unique powerhouse who blends the elegance of Fontaine’s Chief Justice with overwhelming on-field dominance. As a main DPS, Neuvillette commands the battlefield with massive Hydro beams and an incredibly satisfying charge attack mechanic that scales heavily with his HP. He is one of the rare catalyst users who feels like a high-impact carry rather than a support or enabler, capable of dealing tremendous AoE Hydro damage while also offering limited self-healing and visual spectacle with each attack. His playstyle revolves around **charged attacks**, specifically the **Equitable Judgment** beam, which fires a long-range Hydro torrent that pierces through enemies. To unleash this beam, Neuvillette must first **gather Sourcewater Droplets**, which he creates by using his **Elemental Skill, O Tears, I Shall Repay** or by certain team interactions. His Skill summons a wave of Hydro damage that knocks enemies back and creates droplets upon hitting. These droplets restore his stamina and charge, allowing him to fire his devastating charged attack without consuming stamina or health. This loop of using his Skill and charged attack creates a rhythm where Neuvillette constantly weaves in abilities to maintain uptime on his beams. His **Elemental Burst, O Tides, I Have Returned**, is a high-damage AoE Hydro slam that summons a massive cascade of water, dealing damage and spawning additional Sourcewater Droplets. It has a surprisingly short cooldown and low energy cost for how impactful it feels, making it a great tool for clearing large groups or bursting down tougher foes. What sets Neuvillette apart, however, is that **his charged beam damage scales entirely off his max HP**, making HP% his most valuable stat, and allowing for tanky, high-damage builds that don’t compromise survivability. In terms of team composition, Neuvillette performs best when **he is the on-field Hydro DPS**, supported by off-field characters who can either generate reactions or buff his damage. He thrives in **Mono Hydro** setups with characters like Furina, Kokomi, or Yelan, who boost his damage while sustaining or generating energy. Alternatively, **Electro-Charged** teams with Fischl or Beidou can work well, and **Freeze** setups are possible with Cryo supports like Rosaria or Layla, who provide consistent Cryo without stealing field time. Crucially, Neuvillette does not want to be interrupted while channeling his beam, so **shielders like Zhongli or Baizhu** are top-tier pairings to prevent stagger and keep his DPS flowing smoothly. Artifact-wise, Neuvillette’s best set is **Marechaussee Hunter**, which is tailored to him. It increases Normal and Charged Attack damage and gives a Crit Rate boost when HP fluctuates—perfectly matching his self-healing mechanics and HP-scaling beam playstyle. Alternatively, if Marechaussee isn’t available, a mix of **Heart of Depth** and **Tenacity of the Millelith** or **2pc HP%** sets can work. For main stats, you’ll want **HP% on Sands**, **Hydro Damage Bonus on Goblet**, and **Crit Rate or Crit Damage on Circlet** depending on your weapon and overall stat balance. Sub-stats should focus on HP%, Crit stats, and a bit of Energy Recharge for more consistent Burst uptime. As for weapons, Neuvillette’s signature catalyst, **Tome of the Eternal Flow**, is his best-in-slot by a wide margin, offering HP%, Crit Damage, and buffs tailored to his charged attack loops. Among four-star options, **The Prototype Amber** is a decent free-to-play choice for sustain and energy, though the damage falls off in harder content. **The Widsith** is another viable pick that gives temporary massive boosts to Crit or Elemental damage, albeit with some RNG. **Sacrificial Jade** from Battle Pass is also strong, providing Crit Rate and an HP bonus, aligning well with his needs. Neuvillette’s constellations are strong but not necessary for him to perform at a high level. Even at **C0**, he is already capable of dominating the field. That said, **C1** smooths out his energy needs and healing uptime, while **C2** greatly improves his charged attack frequency. **C6** is a massive jump, turning him into an even more absurd DPS with damage bonuses and enhanced beam attacks, but most players will find him more than powerful enough without going beyond C1 or C2. Overall, Neuvillette is a cinematic, fluid, and destructive on-field Hydro DPS who rewards proper stat investment and a bit of patience. His charged attack beam melts enemies in wide arcs, and with the right setup, he can clear even the hardest content with grace and force. Whether you’re drawn to his aesthetic, his lore as Fontaine’s moral arbiter, or his unique high-impact playstyle, Neuvillette delivers an incredibly satisfying experience unlike any other character in *Genshin Impact*.

question: Tell me about QIQI
answer: Qiqi is a five-star Cryo sword user from Liyue who serves as a strong, consistent healer with some unique quirks and limitations. She’s best known for her exceptional ability to keep the entire team’s health topped up through both her skills and Normal Attacks. Though her role is primarily as a healer, Qiqi can also act as a Cryo applier in reaction-focused teams—though she’s not the most efficient in that regard due to her lack of energy generation and limited off-field presence. Still, for players who value survivability and want a reliable Cryo healer, Qiqi is a dependable choice. Her healing comes mainly from her **Elemental Skill, Adeptus Art: Herald of Frost**, which summons a floating talisman that follows the active character. This talisman periodically heals based on Qiqi’s ATK and also restores HP whenever the character performs Normal or Charged Attacks. Because of this, Qiqi encourages an active playstyle where your characters are on the field attacking—making her synergize well with melee-focused characters who like to stay active. The healing is substantial and continuous, making her especially effective in teams that don’t want to slow down for healing rotations. Her **Elemental Burst, Preserver of Fortune**, deals a large AoE Cryo strike and applies the **Fortune-Preserving Talisman** to all enemies hit. Characters who hit those marked enemies heal whenever they deal damage to them, making the Burst an emergency full-team heal tool as well as a secondary source of Cryo application. However, the Burst costs 80 energy and Qiqi doesn’t generate much energy herself, which means she often needs an external battery or a lot of Energy Recharge to use it consistently. While her Cryo application is technically constant during her Skill, it’s not as fast or reliable for triggering reactions like Freeze or Superconduct compared to other Cryo supports like Diona or Rosaria. Qiqi fits best in **sustain-focused teams** where you need consistent healing more than strong reactions or energy utility. She pairs decently with Pyro or Electro characters for Melt or Superconduct teams, but she’s more of a reactive element than a proactive enabler. Some players also use her in **physical damage teams**—often with characters like Eula—since she can trigger Superconduct and provide constant healing while those characters deal damage. She’s also a good fit for beginners or exploration teams where healing and survivability are the top priority. Artifact-wise, Qiqi benefits most from the **Ocean-Hued Clam** set, which boosts her healing and deals bonus damage based on how much she heals—giving her at least some offensive presence. If that set isn’t available or desired, a **2-piece ATK% + 2-piece Healing Bonus** setup can work. Main stats should focus on **ATK%** for both Sands and Goblet, and **Healing Bonus** on the Circlet. Since her healing scales entirely off ATK, stacking ATK through sub-stats and weapon choice is the most effective way to maximize her support role. When choosing weapons for Qiqi, **Sacrificial Sword** is a great choice—it allows her to reset her Skill cooldown and maintain nearly 100% uptime on her healing talisman. **Favonius Sword** is another solid option that helps make up for her low Energy generation by providing particles to the team. If you want to maximize her healing, ATK-focused weapons like **Aquila Favonia** or **Amenoma Kageuchi** also work well, as they raise the raw value of her heals and damage. Qiqi’s constellations aren’t game-changing early on, but they do offer some quality-of-life improvements. Constellation 1 allows her Normal and Charged Attacks to occasionally apply the healing talisman from her Burst, which helps maintain healing without needing to use the Burst itself. Her later constellations increase her Cryo damage or boost the ATK of characters affected by her healing, but overall, Qiqi is mostly complete at C0—what you see is what you get. In summary, Qiqi is an ultra-reliable healer with an unusual ATK-scaling kit and a focus on survivability over team utility or elemental reactions. While she lacks synergy with modern meta reactions and can feel energy-hungry in prolonged fights, her healing output is among the best in the game. For players who value raw healing, want to ensure their team never dips low, or simply enjoy her calm aesthetic and story-driven character, Qiqi is a comforting and loyal support who’ll never let your team fall.

question: Tell me about Heizou
answer: Heizou is a four-star Anemo catalyst user from Inazuma who breaks the mold by functioning as a melee brawler despite wielding a catalyst. His fighting style is fast, fluid, and stylish, drawing inspiration from martial arts and detective flair, making him one of the most unique characters in *Genshin Impact*. Unlike most catalyst users who attack from a distance, Heizou punches and kicks with Anemo-infused strikes, allowing him to be played as either an on-field DPS or an elemental reaction-focused support. His kit rewards strategic play and thoughtful reaction timing, especially when it comes to Swirl-based teams. At the heart of Heizou’s playstyle is his **Elemental Skill, Heartstopper Strike**, which charges up stacks called “Declension” to unleash a powerful strike that deals AoE Anemo damage. Holding the skill allows him to build up to four stacks, and when maxed out, he can trigger a Conviction effect for extra damage. It’s a skill that rewards anticipation and quick decision-making—charging fully gives you more burst, but tapping can be useful in high-speed combat scenarios. His **Elemental Burst, Windmuster Kick**, is a single, stylish flying kick that creates a shockwave of Anemo damage, and it triggers additional Swirl explosions when it reacts with Pyro, Hydro, Cryo, or Electro. This makes Heizou especially potent at setting off multiple reaction-based damage procs in quick succession. Heizou fits most naturally into **Swirl-reaction teams**, where his Anemo abilities can spread elemental statuses and amplify damage through Elemental Mastery scaling. He works exceptionally well with characters that apply consistent off-field elemental damage, such as Xingqiu, Fischl, Xiangling, or Beidou. In these teams, Heizou acts as the on-field driver, rapidly triggering Swirls while dealing high personal damage. Thanks to the Anemo element’s flexibility, he can also be slotted into **Viridescent Venerer** teams to reduce enemy resistance to elements like Pyro or Electro, boosting your main DPS’s effectiveness. Artifact-wise, Heizou’s best set is the **Viridescent Venerer** set. This not only boosts his Swirl damage but also shreds elemental resistance, enhancing the entire team's output. If you’re building him for personal damage, you can consider a two-piece combo like **Viridescent + Gladiator’s Finale** or **Shimenawa’s Reminiscence**, but full Viridescent is almost always more valuable due to its team-wide benefits. His ideal main stats are **Elemental Mastery** or **ATK%** Sands (depending on focus), **Anemo Damage Bonus** on the Goblet, and **Crit Rate or Crit Damage** on the Circlet. If you want to maximize Swirl reaction damage, triple Elemental Mastery works well too. Heizou’s best weapons often depend on whether you’re building him for reaction damage or for raw crit-based DPS. For reaction-focused builds, the **Sacrificial Fragments** or **Maplewood Spear** (if it existed in catalyst form) would be ideal due to high Elemental Mastery. **Solar Pearl** is great for crit-scaling hybrid builds, especially if you’re keeping his Normal Attacks in rotation. **Widsith** is also a very strong option, offering huge bursts of damage when its random buff aligns in your favor. **Dodoco Tales** and **Mappa Mare** can serve as budget options that still perform well in reaction-heavy or free-to-play teams. Heizou’s constellations elevate his performance in interesting ways. His **C1** increases his Elemental Skill's effectiveness and helps him gain Declension stacks faster, improving skill uptime. His **C2** extends the Swirl reaction capability of his Burst, allowing for even more AoE damage through chain reactions. **C4** provides Energy when triggering Swirl, easing his rotation in reaction-heavy teams, and **C6** boosts his CRIT Rate and offers a substantial buff to his Elemental Skill, turning him into a serious contender for main DPS in a well-built team. In essence, Heizou is a fast-paced, reaction-centric brawler who brings a refreshing twist to both catalyst gameplay and Anemo utility. His melee-style combat makes him feel active and engaging, while his potential as a Swirl enabler and debuffer means he can be both stylish and extremely effective. Whether you’re building him to drive a reaction team or simply enjoy his rapid combos and detective aesthetic, Heizou delivers both form and function with flair.

question: Tell me about Thoma
answer: Thoma is a four-star Pyro polearm user from Inazuma who serves as a reliable shielder and support character, best known for his protective abilities and consistent off-field Pyro application. Though not typically used as a main DPS, Thoma finds his niche in teams that benefit from frequent shielding and elemental reactions, particularly in Vaporize, Burgeon, or Overload compositions. His role may be more subtle than that of a damage dealer, but his steady presence on the field and his stylish flame-imbued attacks make him a dependable pick in the right setups. Thoma’s Elemental Skill, **Blazing Blessing**, summons a small Pyro AoE burst while forming a shield based on his max HP. While the initial shield isn’t especially strong compared to characters like Zhongli or Diona, Thoma’s true value comes from his Elemental Burst, **Crimson Ooyoroi**. When activated, this Burst creates a flaming armor effect that triggers additional shields and Pyro damage whenever the active character performs Normal Attacks. These attacks deal coordinated Pyro strikes and refresh Thoma’s shield, allowing him to maintain constant protection and off-field Pyro application throughout the duration of the Burst. In team compositions, Thoma pairs especially well with characters who rely on Normal Attacks or benefit from Pyro reactions. For example, in **Burgeon** teams, Thoma’s off-field Pyro can ignite Dendro Cores created by Hydro and Dendro characters, triggering explosive AoE damage. His shielding also protects teammates from the self-inflicted damage that Burgeon causes. Characters like Nahida and Xingqiu can pair with him to create Dendro and Hydro cores, while Thoma safely detonates them with his Burst. Alternatively, he can serve as a durable Pyro enabler for Normal Attack-focused characters like Yoimiya, especially at higher constellations where he buffs attack speed and improves shield strength. When building Thoma, the **Emblem of Severed Fate** artifact set is widely considered his best-in-slot. It provides Energy Recharge (which he desperately needs due to his high Burst cost) and boosts his Burst damage based on his Energy Recharge stat. If using him in a Burgeon role, a mix of **Flower of Paradise Lost** or **Gilded Dreams** can work well, boosting his Elemental Mastery and thereby increasing his reaction damage. For main stats, prioritize Energy Recharge on the Sands, HP% or EM on the Goblet depending on the role, and HP% or EM again on the Circlet. Sub-stats should focus on Energy Recharge, HP%, and Elemental Mastery. Thoma’s best weapons vary depending on his build. For support and shielding builds, the **Favonius Lance** is excellent due to its energy generation. **The Catch** is also a solid free-to-play option that enhances his Burst and provides some Energy Recharge. If you’re leaning into a Burgeon-focused setup, **Kitain Cross Spear** is an underrated craftable weapon that increases Elemental Mastery and provides energy back after using the Elemental Skill—perfect for reaction-based Thoma. If you’re fortunate enough to have five-star weapons like **Engulfing Lightning**, he can benefit from the massive Energy Recharge and scaling it offers. Thoma’s constellations offer substantial improvements to his utility and team synergy. Constellation 1 increases his shield strength and grants additional energy, helping with his rotation consistency. Constellation 4 boosts the Normal Attack damage of characters under his flaming armor, enhancing synergy with characters like Yoimiya. His Constellation 6 is a major turning point—it grants all party members a 15% Normal Attack speed boost when his shield is active, which significantly increases damage output for on-field DPS characters who rely on rapid attacks. In summary, Thoma is a versatile and reliable support who thrives in reaction-based teams and with characters that need Pyro application and consistent shielding. He may not be a headliner, but his ability to protect allies, trigger reactions, and enhance Normal Attack-based teams makes him a valuable and dependable asset. Whether you’re crafting a Burgeon core or simply looking for a stylish, red-clad fixer to back up your frontliners, Thoma brings warmth, security, and tactical flexibility to your roster.

question: Tell me about Dendro Traveler
answer: The Dendro Traveler marks a significant evolution in the Traveler's capabilities, introduced with the Sumeru region in *Genshin Impact*. This version of the Traveler brings with them access to the Dendro element—a powerful enabler for a variety of elemental reactions that revolve around nature, growth, and catalysis. Unlike previous versions, Dendro Traveler is a strong and relevant unit even for endgame content, thanks to their ability to consistently trigger and support reactions like Bloom, Hyperbloom, Aggravate, and Quicken. As such, their role is often that of an enabler or support, designed to weave Dendro into nearly any team composition. The core of Dendro Traveler’s playstyle lies in their synergy with elemental reactions. Their Elemental Skill, **Razorgrass Blade**, deals AoE Dendro damage in a straight line and has a short cooldown, making it reliable for continuous Dendro application. It's simple but effective for starting reactions and proccing Electro- or Hydro-based responses. However, it’s their Elemental Burst, **Surgent Manifestation**, that truly defines their power. This ability creates a **Lea Lotus Lamp**, a field that pulses with Dendro damage over time and reacts to the element it comes into contact with. If Electro touches the lamp, its attack speed increases, making it better for Aggravate/Spread teams. If Hydro interacts with it, the AoE of its pulses grows, supporting Bloom-based teams. This flexibility makes Dendro Traveler incredibly adaptable. In terms of team building, Dendro Traveler fits seamlessly into many reaction-based teams, acting as a core enabler in both Hyperbloom (Dendro + Electro + Hydro) and Quicken (Dendro + Electro) comps. They work particularly well alongside characters like Nahida, Kuki Shinobu, Raiden Shogun, Fischl, Xingqiu, Yelan, or even Alhaitham, depending on your goal. In Hyperbloom, for example, Dendro Traveler and Hydro units create Dendro Cores that your Electro unit (like Shinobu) triggers for massive AoE damage. In Aggravate teams, they help consistently trigger Dendro so Electro DPS units can take advantage of reaction-based crit scaling. Artifact-wise, the best set for Dendro Traveler is **Deepwood Memories**. This set not only boosts Dendro damage but also shreds enemy Dendro resistance, which benefits both the Traveler and any other Dendro characters in your team. If another team member is already using Deepwood, Traveler can run **Instructor** (for EM support) or **Noblesse Oblige** for a teamwide ATK buff. Main stats should prioritize Energy Recharge on the Sands (due to their high Burst cost), Dendro Damage Bonus on the Goblet, and Crit Rate, Crit Damage, or Elemental Mastery on the Circlet depending on your build focus. Sub-stats should aim for Energy Recharge, EM, and Crit stats as appropriate. As for weapons, **Favonius Sword** is a top-tier option because it helps generate energy for the whole team and keeps the Burst rotation consistent. **Sapwood Blade**, a craftable Sumeru weapon, is also excellent, giving Energy Recharge and dropping an Elemental Mastery-boosting leaf for the next character that picks it up—perfect for reaction-based teams. Other strong options include **Sacrificial Sword** for an extra Elemental Skill usage or **Freedom-Sworn** if you want to lean into reaction boosting and team buffs. Dendro Traveler's constellations are fairly impactful, and since they’re obtainable for free through story progression, they offer good value. Their early constellations improve the duration and strength of their Elemental Burst, while later ones enhance their Dendro application and reaction support. Notably, Constellation 2 increases the duration of the Lea Lotus Lamp and the buffs it receives based on elements it interacts with, improving your reaction uptime. At Constellation 6, the Traveler begins to provide buffs to the active character’s Elemental Mastery while inside the Lamp’s field, further enhancing reaction damage and cementing their role as a valuable team support. To sum it up, the Dendro Traveler is the most versatile and relevant form of the Traveler to date. They offer strong and reliable Dendro application, team utility, and elemental flexibility, especially in reaction-based teams.
